description:
love this bakery.

but making this review so I don't forget

French Garlic Bun - skip. bread is always hard (2nd time buying). Go for the rectangular garlic bread!
author: Yeanne L.

description:
So, I decided after the pineapple bun debacle, to try to get a selection of fancy cakes for dessert tonight.  They're pretty and I was feeling generous. Hubs picked it up and we sat down to enjoy our desserts after dinner. We purchased the mocha, peach and strawberry cake so that we could try a few flavors. 

I didn't know you could make cake filling taste like plastic foam till I had this cake. It was awful. Though it was just slightly sweeter than average Asian cakes, which is good, the texture of the filling is best described as a marshmallow foam. I actually stopped chewing and looked over at my husband with my sad panicked face while my mouth hung open. My eyes screaming, "What have I done?!? To deserve this?!? I wanted to trust you, Sheng Kee!!" I didn't want to chew the foam. Being a good Asian, I tried to power through it but hubs made the call and swooped it up and away before we wasted anymore calories on this cake. 

With all the other fancy Chinese bakeries around now like Paris baguette and 85 degrees. I don't see a bright future for these guys. It's sad. They failed the authenticity test on their baos and when I came back to try their cakes, I was disappointed once again. 

Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me. I won't be coming in to try your latest "Dirty" bun for a third attempt. (Who wants to eat something named Dirty anyway? The marketing department needs a taking to.).
author: Marie L.

description: Their buns are pretty good. I like how you get a tray and pick up whatever  in the display case without anyone having to help you. Watch out though, their deep fry chicken/fish/pork buns aren't that good. There isn't enough grease in it. The quality of the meat isn't all that great. Otherwise, the rest of the selection is worth your time. If you buy enough buns, they will give you a box.
author: Jeff H.

description: We came here and got a green tea filled pastry, a cream bun, and a fruit pastry.  I'm not sure if it was because we came a little later in the day, around 6:00, but they didn't have many selections left. The pastries were average and tasted a little old but overall it was okay. The staff were nice and the place is clean.
author: Anna J.

description: This bakery is so cute! They have an array of lunch items like kawaii sandwiches, buns, flavored breads, small cakes, & yogurt. I got their boba milk tea, chocolate walnut cookies, and strawberry yogurt. It was all absolutely delicious, almost too cute to eat ! I especially loved their yogurt, it looked imported from China, which would make sense since it wasn't as sweet as the American yogurts I have tried. It had the perfect amount of tartness and it did not feel heavy in my stomach like yogurt usually feels after I eat it. So kudos to Sheng Kee for having a yogurt I can actually eat! I will definitely visit this place again next time I am in SF area.
author: Esca N.

description: I had a BBQ pastry. Unfortunately it was mostly the pastry and not much bbq inside. The positive of this place is the dining area while many bakeries in the area has only take out feature. Lots of local folks were sitting, eating, drinking and chatting here.
author: Aya T.

description:
Came here since had $20 gift certificates to use. Not a fan of Sheng Kee since its main ingridients are lard, sugar and food coloring. So I tried looking for the most healthy stuff. 

So I got dinner rolls (least sweet), whole wheat walnut raisin bread (not that sweet but does have purple food coloring), almond sponge cake (strong artificial almond odor), pinapple bun, red bean bun, and a brioche (mildly sweet and not too sweet). 

I also took a few photos and you can see the nutritional facts for the dinner rolls and walnut bread. Its hard choosing the stuff you think is healthy.
author: Organic T.

description: Your average chinese buns. Most of the buns or  pastries average price are between $1.50 to $2.30 depending on what you get. Decent price. I got about  6 buns which total close to $10. This place looks very clean. I like how this place lets you pick your own buns by using a tray and tongs. Just have to browse and pick your favorites. I would rather do that since its more comfortable than the workers who have to do it for you and dont feel rush too. Their buns are good for snacks. Decent selections of buns and pastries
author: Julie N.

description:
Their pastries remind me of 85degrees. Came here on a Sunday morning to take to a friends place for breakfast. They have a lot of options and their pastries are super tasty. I ordered 8 parties and 2 coffees and it was less than $20 which I thought was a good value.
However, I have to warn the coffee is not great.
author: Mariana V.

description:
Fresh. Cheap. Good. 

Those are the words you want to hear describing any bakery. Sheng Kee Bakery delivers!

Cocktail Buns. Dan Tat. Pineapple Buns. 

Those are my go-to, no-fail bakery choices here. Sheng Kee Bakery also has Almond Cookies, Eclairs, Fruit Tarts, Macaroons, Croissant Sammies, & other bakery goodies like the seasonal Moon Cake, but it's all about those...

Cocktail Buns for me. 

The Cocktail Buns are so soft, so buttery, so eff addictive good! And maybe the best part, so darn cheap! My advice to you... ask for the Cocktail Buns and if it's warm... ask for plenty! And thank me later, buttercup. 

Sheng Kee Bakery is located in the outer Sunset on Irving St. just past 19th Ave. It is on the Lincoln Way side of Golden Gate park so great for picnic ideas too. I've been coming here for years, ahem decades, pre-yelp and it has never failed me. It's your typical "Chinese Bakery", but a notch above with cleanliness, organization, & super friendly workers. Fresh. Cheap. Good. Oh baby!
author: Eric R.

description:
My family and I went here to get a few goodies before heading out to the California Academy of Science. It was definitely a treat. 

They had quite a few pastries to choose from. I did not know where to begin.  Anything with taro root is very popular right now and this place did not disappoint in that department lol. 

I like how you grab your own tray and tongs, so that way you get to pick and choose what you want. I also like how the pastries were in  plastic containers where you can open and close them. 

The pastries were pretty good and not overwhelmingly sweet. We will definitely go back when we go out this way again.
author: Crisel M.

description:
Decades ago, we trekked all the way to SF to buy the *right* breads.  It is a must-stop whenever we were in the neighborhood.  Of course, we make our pilgramage each year during the Moon Festival for the highly coveted moon cakes.

Then, so many branches opened in south bay. But they are all those modern Taiwan style breads. Not the original Russian ones.  That's OK, we enjoyed them equally well.

Then, that day, we stopped by this original Sheng Kee, for nostalgia mostly.  Sigh...

They became the same as their new south bay branches.  Why was I surprised?  The transformation probably started from this store.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
Credit cards accepted for purchased only MORE than $10!

Your average Sheng Kee Bakery with OK service. It's a bit smaller than the one in South SF so I felt like they don't have as great of a selection in pastries. However, I felt like their cake selection was about the same. 

I've only tried their egg tarts and pineapple buns here and they're just your normal Sheng Kee quality. Really tasty, but also a bit expensive. With all these Asian bakeries in the vicinity, (like Pineapple King Bakery) I tend to opt out on Sheng Kee unless I really feel like treating myself.
author: Andrea K.

description: July 4, I decided to give them a try since we were in the area and wanted Pineapple King bakery in the first place. My brother and I were really excited and got 3 items which came to a total of around $7.  I handed the cashier a $20 and happily received the change back from her but as I was heading out, I realized she had only given me $2 in change and not $12. I went back and asked for more change but she said in broken English something about how I gave them a 10 but they'll check for me when they close and call. Great maybe they'll catch it. They called and adamantly insisted that they were correct. Not only did my brother see I handed them a 20, but I did not have any 10s on me because I had gone to the atm before for cash and only had 20s.  I'm very disappointed that this had to happen during my first time at this location but since they took 10 and didn't admit it, they lost a customer. Be careful at this location and make sure you say the amount you are handing them. I'm giving them a 2 star because I'm going to eat their bread.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
1 star for the service. 3 stars for the raspberry mango mousse and the two Portuguese tarts. 3 items for $30. 
It took them a few minutes to wrap up the raspberry mango mousse. When I asked for a bag (because I had 2 boxes of food), they said "Fifteen cents." I only had credit card. Then they said "$10 minimum." Needless to say, I walked out without a bag and all of the kiwis and strawberries fell off from the raspberry mango mousse. Either they can work on their service or I can work on my juggling skills. The taste for everything was fine: not too sweet, but sweet enough.
author: Ato Z.

description:
I hate this kind of review and often doubt the veracity of such reviews, but now I'm going to do it. Normally I'd let it go, but it was just too disgusting. 

A friend brought us a box of coconut buns and we tucked in, really enjoying them. Unfortunately, I found a fingernail in my bun. Initially I thought it was a really tough piece of unshredded coconut, but upon further inspection (see photo), it was definitely a nail. 

I'm still giving them two stars because the coconut bun was really good. Except for the nail. Sadly that wasn't the first time I've had a nail in my bun BOOM!
author: Jeff R.

description: Despite the reviews this place is by far the most diverse, interesting and best quality in the city. Unlike others they are great at many things not just popular for one item.
author: j. g.

description:
It's so sad that this bakery hires imbeciles to work their counter. I've always loved their pastries, but poor training in customer service is a complete turn off. The cashier rings me up and doesn't bother to ask if I needed a bag. Seeing that I'm carrying things left and right (cake, breads and pastries) she simply says that she forgot and did not think about it. I asked for a bag and she refuses to give me one, and asks me to place all the pastries and breads inside my cake box and to tie the remaining items to the ribbon tied to the box. She reluctantly gave me a small paper bag and said that I should have cash to pay the 0.25 charge if I want a bag. Sadly I didn't have cash, and she should have asked. 

Very poor experience.
author: Alex C.

description: Very bad customer services,  the employees sometimes yell to the customers.    I only go there when I didn't have enough cash.  The smaller bakery on the same block is much better in terms of both products & services, but only take cash.   If you are fans of Sheng Kee,  the one on 9th ave is much much better.
author: Lillia B.

description:
This location is in the heart of San Francisco old china town. You do feel like you're in China when you're walking around here. This or the one on Irving and 9th Ave are both great. They always have fresh pastries and bread.  Love the whole wheat here.

Their toast bread varieties are so fluffy, delicate, and with an awesome light touch of sweetness. I don't like whole wheat but Sheng Kee style while wheat is just superb! 

I definitely miss this place.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
I appreciate the variety of buns and cakes they have but I feel like they're getting to be overpriced. Sure, a bun that's around $2-ish is not pricey but it feels so when the flavor is meh and there's other bakeries around the block which taste slightly better even if they don't have a large selection. I've tried several of their cakes and didn't like any. 

A perk is that they do individually wrap each bun upon checkout.
author: Julie L.

description: I love the baked goods here, but one of the coconut buns I bought on Saturday, 4/10/17 had a metal piece in it that hurt my tooth. I'm glad I didn't give it to my kids to eat! Perhaps they need to do a little more quality control/be aware of their supplier.
author: Susie F.

description:
It was an afternoon in San Francisco and my pops wanted some coffee. Lucky my cousin Steve, & his beautiful wife Priscilla know all the good spots for coffee and a little something, something.

Sheng Kee Bakery is where we ended up at..........for my island peeps - what is "Sheng Kee Bakery?" 

To put it simply.......it's like a St. Germain Bakery that we have here on the islands.

Apparently Sheng Kee Bakery is pretty big, with locations all over like - San Francisco, Berkeley, Cupertino, Richmond, Milpitas, Union City, Brisbane, San Mateo, &  Daly City.

They serve the standard buns/breads, and some Chinese treats that I like - (Custard Tart), as well as some fancy pansy cakes. 

I originally was gonna eat a custard tart, but upon passing the cake display, my plans changed, as I decided on a Green Tea Mousse Cake.

Ummmmmm, Green Tea Mousse Cake.........with a strong green tea powdered flavoring on top!  Noms! To complement my afternoon treat, I had a cup of Peet's Coffee too! 

This place also sells tea's, coffee, & that Milk ball tea thing-a-ma-jig...........sorry, I don't drink that stuff (maybe I'm missing out, who knows). 

Anyways, a pretty cool bakery. The place was clean, service was fast, but unfortunately there is only metered street parking here. 

A great place to stop by for a snack!
author: Fran C.

description:
I went to a chinese bakery when visiting a friend in Queens like 4 years ago. I had this chesnut pastry there that I still fantasize about. I love chestnuts, hazelnuts, pistachios, almonds, all those goodies.
But, I digress. The coconut pastry did not disappoint. My friends had a savory toast w/ bacon and other stuff, and a jasmine matcha pastry (which they were on the fence about). The coconut pastry was a dollar, I should've gotten more for tasting purposes, but health.
author: Marin C.

description:
This is where it started.
For me, the first and largest location in the City, strategically on Irving Street as budding Chinese businesses like San Tung and Wonderful Foods were the neighborhood draws.  We know how the street evolved to be Clement Street South in the avenues.  
Now, there are even more food and drink spots yet this staple still hustles and bustles unlike any other bakery in the area.  
My recent trips are mostly for their tea eggs, 2 for $1.99, that sits in a warming pot by the register, mainly for a friend.  This is only available at this location.  In the past, my main buys were pineapple shortcakes or red bean buns.  Well, since increased competition from that Taiwan coffee place in Newark and Cupertino, they really needed to step up their game.  Hence, the three recent pastry purchases brought smiles to my face (pics below).  One afternoon, being parched, I had their $1.99 mango green tea which hit the spot.
The new menu offerings also gave me an opportunity to see how this neighborhood changed and try Tpumps teas.  Nice perks.
author: Mike C.

description:
This location is okay, and I do like the Sheng Kee Bakery chain generally speaking as well as all of their products.

We had the SLC Mango, which was a slice for $3.39 and it was okay, not spectacular as most of their other deserts I've had here have been.

It's similar to JJ Bakery, 85 Degrees, and those other Chinese / Taiwanese bakeries in California (SF to LA) I've been to.

This location has seating inside to enjoy eating a snack too.

Parking is typical of the Sunset District and shopping area of Irving Street, a little bit of luck, a dash of good karma, and a lot of luck goes a long way.
author: Rick S.

description: #82 I was craving a pineapple bun while I was in the area but they didn't have any plain ones left. The lady working was nice enough to check in the back if they had any leftover. I spotted some brioche that looked EXACTLY like the brioche at 85° Bakery, but it tasted kinda different. Like less sweet. Or maybe I'm just trippin. I also tried the thin almond cookies but they were way too crunchy. Meh, I'll just stick with their fruit cakes.
author: Kirstie P.

description:
One of my favorite asian bakeries is Sheng Kee. This time, I went with my friends and we ordered some pastries. Usually the bakery is filled with people, but there wasn't much people there at the time I went. 

My friend got a flaky danish with green tea filling and a butter poundcake. However, when she dug into the danish pastry, there was very little green tea and it was located at the bottom of the pastry. It was disappointing to see how a wonderful looking pastry had little filling. We noted to not get this pastry next time.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I like this place because they have different cakes that are really good and very pretty this place is clean the staff are a little on the rude side but I'll come here again for the cakes.
author: Michele T.

description: Sheng Kee is a stable for Asian bakeries here in San Francisco. You can't beat the feeling of coming in and filling a tray with both sweet and savory pastries. Parking in this area is horrific but just take your time. There are tons of people doing all kinds of illegal driving maneuvers
author: Diego A.

description:
Great bakery on irving street!
Four stars because the service is sometimes a hit or miss. But for the most part, people are decently friendly. Maybe it's my fault because I only speak English. 
This bakery has amazing bread!
My favorites are the custard bun, red bean bun, and the green onion bun. YUM! I definitely want to try more, but my options are a little limiting because I don't eat meat. Overall, delicious food!
author: Robyn S.

description: I've tried BBQ buns, almond croissants, green tea moon cake, pineapple croissants, and can't remember the rest. Its not amazing, but it's not bad. It's clean, and the pastries are all labeled.
author: Ha D.

description:
I'm a big fan of their mocha rolls and their cakes! They always look so pretty in the display case, and you definitely won't be disappointed. I'm a fan of the mocha roll especially because of how light and not overly sweet it is. As for the cakes, I really like their mango mousse and black forest cake. Yum! Whoever came up with designing the cakes, props to you.

They have a good variety of asian pastries here, from pineapple buns to taro buns and other fun little cute ones you probably never heard of. Their bread is always fresh; when you poke it, it's always very soft! This location is smaller than the original further down Irving, but they offer the same stuff.

I guess the reason why I give three stars, no matter how much I love their pastries, is because of the milk tea. Sad to say, but when I got it (it was $2 with pearls which isn't bad at all, however...) it was too sweet, and what was disappointing was that I found chunks of sugar at the bottom of my drink. It was like the kind of sugar used for coffee (sugar in the raw? something like that.) and bleh.. it was gross. So yeah.. don't get it.
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Yummy & fairly standard Asian bakery. Good savory items, okay pricing. Gets busy weekend mornings w/the older crowd, tables can sometimes be left messy :(

Good place to s too by for some carbs to munch on.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Sheng Kee has a pretty upscale decor compared to other Chinese bakeries, but their food is no better. 

At a glance, you might be a little overwhelmed with the large selection of baked buns that they have. But don't be fooled, the ones on the shelf are rarely fresh. Cleanliness is also a problem. I've spotted little crawlers inside the store on several occasions.

Even considering all that, Sheng Kee is still an alright place. They don't have the best birthday cakes, but they have presentable ones at a reasonable price. (Around $20) If you want a cute one, they have a cake shaped as a head of a bear and a pig : )

They wrap things up rather nicely so this is a good place to stop by if you're getting things for the office!
author: Ringo M.

description: love love love this place. thier pineaple curstard bun is amazing. Only this store has the best custard bun. Ive tried other stores and others dont have that much fillings inside as this one. staff is friendly and quick. Egg tart, the newly cheese tart and green tea cheese tart are awesome too :) Must go place when I visit sunset.
author: Tina H.

description:
Sheng Kee has been in the Sunset, on Irving Street for what seems like decades. I used to love this place and was to be my go-to place to pick up an entire cake or fruit tarte. But over the years, prices have risen so much, that I wish my investments have the same % increase. 

Now that I've lived in LA (626) for about 7 years, I've discovered many other Asian bakeries that seem so much better. 

The selection of baked goodies here is nothng spectacular. They carry the usual pineapple buns, egg tarts and the common savory pastries. The sizes are not too generous, and they really have nothing original or stands out. The freshness is debatable. On rare occasions do they bring out fresh items while I was in there holding a tray, compared to JJ in Arcadia or 85C in SoCal where they're constantly bringing fresh stuff out from the kitchen. 

Overall, it's a decent bakery that serves the Sunset crowd. There is often a line to pay and the place often seems crowded. Perhaps it's because the place is small and there's only one cashier counter. Still, some items in the display case do look good and are worth trying. 

Tip: Try the honey cake for about $1.50 or the fruit tart for about 20 bucks. Both are memorable.
author: James L.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery has a wide selection of sweet and savory and plain breads and pastries in Asian and European styles. They also serve sandwiches, soups, and Peet's Coffee. 
Each time I have gone to Sheng Kee, the quality has been consistently good. Their BBQ pork buns are always solid, and especially delicious when they're hot out of the oven. I like their sweet buns such as the taro bun and the yam bun. Their chocolate croissants and turnovers are also top notch. 
The staff are always friendly and helpful. The prices are well marked and quite reasonable. While, for example, the pork buns here are $1.80 instead of more traditional dim sum bakeries which may sell for $0.75, the quality is more consistent. 
The bakery does feel like a chain, which it is, but the quality makes it a good neighborhood staple.
author: Allxie C.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery is a nice place to go if you're looking for some Asian style pastries. There is a wide selection of baked good to choose from. Though I enjoyed going through all the choices, I felt that a few things held Sheng Kee from being an outstanding place to eat.

First... the good! When you first go into the restaurant, you are bombarded with a ton of choices. There are numerous items ranging from pineapple buns to pork sung rolls,  to sandwiches and even cakes. And looking at the price is great... because most items are under $1.50. Grab a tray, get a wax sheet on it... and go crazy!

If you are a fan of the corn, ham, and egg filled pastries, you'll enjoy this place. I, for one, am not as big on these types of desserts/baked goods. They lack some refinement to me, as I tend to go for pastries that have a lighter taste. The desserts here tend to be heavier and more dense/filling. I'm also a bit wary of the overall quality of the food. Again, it's just not as refined as I would like it to be.

If you're in the mood for something a bit more savory, Sheng Kee has a few items for you, but not much. There are some bbq pork pastries, as well as curry turnovers and a chicken pie... that's really it, though, unless you count the pre-made sandwiches in the cold case. I would have loved to have the chance to get more savory items.

All-in-all, Sheng Kee is a nice place to stop by for some very affordable (and filling) Asian baked goods. The items you can get here are decent, but they won't blow you away or make you say 'wow!'

This place is 'A-OK'! But I can't say it goes above that.
author: Luke C.

description:
I've gone in here before, for a pastry or something -- didn't pay attention, but they were fine.

Friday I got a chicken salad sandwich.  HOOBOY!  Yummy bread, tasty chicken salad, with fruit (!)  and just overall the best chicken salad sandwich I've had in my memory.  And very, very reasonably priced.  But really, if it'd been pricier, I wouldn't have cared, b/c .... BEST EVER.

I'm goin' back to try other things, that's for sure.
author: Chet M.

description: I have enjoyed most of their stuff, but their vanilla roll is so disgusting...it tastes gross -- like gummy sweet cardboard....
author: Jihyun L.

description:
A little difficult trying to find parking, but not impossible. It is meter parking. 

They have a great selection of all kinds of baked goods! I chose out a birthday cake for my friend. It's the one with a variety of fruits as the topping and inside is white cake with peaches. YUM! The fruits tasted very fresh! I love this cake!

They employees here weren't exactly friendly, but I was just in and out of this place so I didn't care much for their attitude.
author: Thanh B.

description:
This is a great Asian bakery staple in SF. Is everything in their store perfect? No. But most of the items you will find are pretty tasty and the variety of options never disappoints. They also have lots of good "specials" every once in a while. I only buy their fresh breads/pastries though so I can't speak on their cakes. It's a great place to pass by and just pick up a snack or two...or three. 

My personal faves are the taro breads that come in so many iterations. Their savory pork sung, red bean and chocolate varieties are great as well. 

Solid place that I can always rely on to pick up asian bakery goods at or introduce people to if they're new or visiting because it always has options and delivers well on taste most of the time.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Sheng Kee is a pretty foolproof bakery with fresh breads/buns that are not overly sweet or oily. My favorites are the taro buns and pineapple red bean buns. The green onion buns can verge on overly oily and a little too creamy for my liking. I'm a huge fan of the beef curry horns (available near the register because they're hot). I consider them an indulgence because their exterior is extremely buttery and flakey, with just the right amount of golden browning. The interior has slightly sweet curried beef, and overall the little horn is aromatic and delicious. 

Note: $10 minimum for credit cards!
author: Michelle S.

description:
I recently visited the near 9th Avenue and was less than impressed by their offerings.  With the discovery of another location closer to my girlfriend's apartment, and the specials advertised in their window, I decided to give it another try.

We shared a variety of buns including the ham & egg, ham & cheese, bacon & corn, taro, and curry beef, as well as a tiger tea to wash it all down.  My favorites were definitely the ones with ham and bacon in them, but the biggest surprise was how much I enjoyed their tiger tea.  It may only be a mix of thai tea and milk tea, but it was surprisingly refreshing and enjoyable.  I'm actually quite excited and optimistic about going back to try their other varieties very soon.

It's location may be difficult to get to by car since parking is sparse in the area, but it's just close enough for my girlfriend and I to walk to regularly.  I'm a big fan of this location over the one closer to UCSF and I'd even say the service was actually quite good here.  Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area!

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Been going here on and off for more than 10 years.  The prices over the years has been going up, but then again look at the location of this place and the economy.

The buns have been good and consistent.  The service has been quick and responsive.  I have even tried there milk teas here.  It's just as good as the other million boba tea places on this street.  However,  not much in terms of tea flavors.  Then a gain this place isn't a tea place.
author: Guest U.

description: You can always count on sheng kee to deliver weird Western inspired asian bakery stuffs. I'm here lit as fuck and gnawing on garlic bread and looking wistfully deep in thought while 80s music pump through the buttery scented air.
author: Anchovy G.

description:
I like this Sheng Kee more than the one in the Inner Sunset. I love the Portuguese egg tarts, the shredded pork bun, and the buns filled w/ custard. Those are my absolute faves. I like this one because it has more options then the other one. I always like the Tiger Milk Tea too, which is the only place you can get it I think, but I'm sure other boba places would do it too. My definite to to for asian pastires when in the outer sunset. :) 

Only accepts credit cards if you spend more that $5... which is always pretty easy for me!
author: Julie L.

description:
This place is getting increasingly more expensive over the years. But I guess that's the price for living in San Francisco. Anyways, this where we get our cakes for family occasions and birthdays, and I don't recall anything significantly terrible about prior experiences. The establishment is well-lit and there is a large selection of baked goods all neatly organized. The building feels pretty spacious as well. However, if you are driving to Sheng Kee, I'd recommend you don't drive at all. Parking is true terror, especially during the weekends. Traffic is usually congested around the area. It's way better to walk or bus there if you are nearby. 

As for the food, I can only review their cakes and custard bread. They are moist and delicious. Like I said, we've never had an issue with the cake before, albeit there have been times where there was a little too much frosting and too little cake. The food here is good. I'd recommend it!
author: Golden H.

description:
I'm generally not too crazy about Asian style breads or cakes. However, there's something about those individually wrapped breads and pastries at Sheng Kee that just seem so appealing and irresistible. Seriously, I'm a sucker for good packaging and presentation. 

My mom prolly buys bread from Sheng Kee almost weekly. Hence, I've tried the thick toast, egg, wheat, raisin, red bean and taro breads. Not my favorite, but pretty good especially when fresh. I also tried some of their baked buns both savory and sweet. Not too crazy about those either. I do like their little moon cakes though! The jasmine and oolong tea flavored ones are my favorites....besides the white lotus one. 

The cakes at SK are like most Asian cakes - not too sweet, usually some sort of sponge cake with light cream. They generally look very nice and are always a hit when you bring them to a party or some sort of celebration. A few of my favorites are the mango mousse, chocolate and mocha cakes. I have also tried the taro filled one, which I thought was OK as was the green tea cake. Most of the cakes are decorated very nicely and topped with fruit. The cakes are also reasonably priced and it's nice that you don't necessarily have to special order (unless you want to get something specific or large sheet cake)....very convenient if you need to just drop in to pick up a cake since they always have a bunch ready made. You can also buy some of the cakes by the slices if you can't eat a whole one.

Parking at this location can be tough as you all know Irving street is poppin'. You may need to circle the block a few times if you're looking for the metered spots. Otherwise, park in the residential streets a block or two away and you should be fine.
author: Liv A.

description:
This location is significantly more spacious than the ones nearby (namely, the one on 9th, the one at westlake, and the one at ranch 99) which sometimes means that it boasts some more "interesting" items. 

Today, mom came and picked up a fruit cake, but while exploring, found an item called "cake sushi"...it comes as 4 slices of their sponge cake rolled in toasted coconut on the outside and layered with ham, pork sung, cucumbers, and mayo inside. I know, sounds kind of peculiar...but this sweet/savory thing is something Sheng Kee actually does pretty well. I was pleasantly surprised by this cake sushi.

Sheng Kee likes to experiment. Sometimes it works: chocolate pineapple bun and milky brioche...and other times, it just doesn't: green tea mochi bun. Regardless of the hits and misses though, my family likes coming to this Sheng Kee because it's a one stop shop on Irving (i.e. this one is near Sunset Super and Lam Hoa Thuan).
author: Elaine Y.

description: Place is decent but service is not good. All they care is making money and try to sell you stuff that's a day old at regular price. Be careful when you get your change back. They tend to short change you. It's not the first time it happen. That's why I'm posting it this time.
author: dave w.

description:
I came in yesterday to buy a cake and they have a pretty good selection. I usually like going to Sheng Kee for the consistency of taste. Usually I fulfill my cravings all the same. They are priced more expensive than other Chinese bakery. There seemed to be a much smaller selection at this location. 

Anyways, on to the cake: ive tried their taro cake and that really realllly good. This time, I was deciding between strawberry mousse and French chestnut mousse cake. I was dissapointed that both cakes have a very deceiving exterior. Go see the picture. Initially I thought it was only the strawberry one, but I asked the worker and she said there's only one layer of mousse inside. I ended up getting the chestnut cake. They accept credit card!!  Also, they decorated a piece of white chocolate with the birthday greeting, which is a nice service. 

My family LOVES chestnut, but the cake was all a lie. There was a thin layer around the outside of the cake to give it an appearance of having two layers of mousse, but in reality, there was more cake than mousse. Needless to say, I was disappointed. If anything, Sheng kee could've added a disclaimer!The cake doesn't taste as good as Chinese fruit cake nor the chestnut cake from Napoleon in Chinatown. For the taste and value, I dont like the two matched. In the future, I do not plan on returning to this Sheng Kee this bakery for cake or pastries.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
Just merely okay in my book. The milk also wasn't all that great, either. Maybe it was an off day, who knows. 

During my visit, I may have been yelled at a few times. The positive side being that I was acknowledged by the employees rather than being ignored. I'll take what I can get. 

Will try again on a luckier day...
author: Aren A.

description:
Somehow, this location of Sheng Kee was even more disappointing than the other. Mainly because the pastries seemed poorly made and not very fresh, and the service was just awful. 

Apricot pastry: No apricot flavor, oddly bitter and tasted a most rotten
"Rough" pineapple cake: Not sure how to translate it into English, but these were less sweet than the popular Taiwanese pineapple cakes and also tasted off, like the pineapples weren't fresh
Croissant: Flaky and light, but really, really greasy-feeling from all the butter

The women working behind the counter were incredibly rude--snippy, curt and bizarrely angry. Even speaking the same language as them (Mandarin) yielded a severe deficiency in courtesy. The clientele included some creepy old Chinese men who don't mind ogling you if you're female and over the age of 12. While there was far more seating here, more than of the tables and chairs were filthy and covered in crumbs, dirt and miscellaneous other things not found in nature.
author: Josephine L.

description:
If you are from Socal, this bakery is similar to JJ bakery, or 85 degrees. Not quite as big and doesn't have as much variety as 85.

I mainly come here for the brioche. It's fresh and cheap! It's perfect for my french toast! I have tried a few of their pastries and are pretty standard for a typical Taiwanese/chinese bakery. 

They have another location on Irving and 10th (?). That store seems to be better kept, and the employees are much nicer. Ultimately it doesn't matter in terms of buying bread, but was a pleasant surprise. Let's be honest, customer service usually isn't a priority for  Asian places.
author: Thuy N.

description:
Great place for quick grab n go Asian pastries and baked goods. It can be pretty busy at times here, and the usual crowd can lack manners.. But the establishment is clean and efficiently run. They have a fair amount of tables inside, but it's not really an environment conducive to studying or staying for very long.

As for the goods, well, they're quite good! Prices per pastry range from $.99 to $2ish each. Everything seems fresh, and you can frequently see employees bringing out fresh batches to restock the shelves. Some of my favorites include the taro buns, pork sung buns, coconut buns... It's hard to go wrong here! Actually, I usually stay away from the meat ones since they're not kept heated, and thus bacteria can grow quickly.

Anyhow, Sheng Kee is quick, inexpensive, and has something for any carb lover!
author: Andrew T.

description: Terrific Chinese pastries and bread. Wonderful cakes also. A little pricey but the quality is definitely  there. The best fruit tarts I have ever tasted, about $26.00. Apple turnovers are my favorite, $3.00 per. Cash Only!
author: Dirk D.

description: Years and years ago, this brand of bakery used to be good. Breads are now stale and flavorless. I only come back for their green tea cakes. Nothing more.
author: Hoang T.

description: The Fresh Strawberry cake is mind blowing.  We've gotten two now and it's amazing.  The cream is light and fresh, the cake is moist.  Yummy.
author: Shannon M.

description: Terrible. Terrible. Terrible. I bought the Blueberry half Moon yesterday at this store，12/2/2014。when I back home I took out everything ，I found out the date was12/1. It's out of date, and the cake was moldy .I wouldn't come back again, it wastes my money. Fortunately, I find out and haven't eat that.
author: Vivian L.

description:
If I need a quick snack this is the place to go. The variety is amazing! It's good if you are looking for both something salty and something sweet. They have milk tea too. It's not super flavorful but it's cheap. I do recommend the tiger milk tea. 

If you got a birthday to celebrate, I recommend the cakes.  They are just precious.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery is a cute bakery on Irving Street.  They have tons of freshly baked breads, pastries, tarts, and cakes.  Also, they have $.99 boba!

I bought a couple of breads, some cakes, and got the passion fruit green tea with boba.  The drink was okay, boba was good and chewy.

I wish I could tell you how the breads tasted, but my aunt's dog ate all the bread out of my tote bag.  All that was left were the wrappers/bags.  Since the dog basically ate everything without a trace of crumbs, I can assume that they were both pretty tasty.

As for the cakes, I accidentally forgot them in my aunt's fridge and am now back in LA.  I'm sure her tummy is also enjoying the cakes as well!
author: Stephanie L.

description: I really enjoyed the blueberry puff, it was mostly puff pastry with some blueberries at the bottom. I also like the almond pastries and the fruit pastry with custard filling. I was a bit adventurous and tried the pre-packaged date pastries...I was expecting something sweet but it was more of a savory/ sour flavor which I was not a fan of.
author: Bernadette S.

description: Been going there for years. They have variety of cakes, buns, bakeries. Reasonable price and can't wait to go back.
author: Dear J.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery reminds me of a bakery I loved back in LA. 

It's always clean, well-stocked, and full of people hustling and bustling--fighting over the bread with their claw like tongs. They take credit card, but you have to have over a $5 purchase..just bring cash in case ! 

My favorites are the pineapple bread, the green onion hotdog bread, and spongecake. You should try those! They are to die-for. 

For most newbies, please note: don't use your fingers. 
You take a tray, cover it with one of the white papers, and then take a tong to select your bread. It seems silly that I should mention this, but I've seen way too many people using their fingers instead of tongs. 

Honestly, I always take the bus when I come to this location so I never have problems finding parking, but I do know it is crazy on the weekends because everyone likes to come on Irving Street in their free time. Good luck to those driving and hurrah to those riding the bus!
author: Emily F.

description:
Delicious self-serve bakery. Loved the taro braid, the egg custard tart, and the red bean bun. Also tried the curry beef horns and chive bread - against my sister's recommendation - and was underwhelmed. It wasn't bad, but it was expensive for what it was.

Conclusion: I wouldn't bother with the savory pastries again, but the sweets are awesome-delicious!!
author: Joseph M.

description:
Great Chinese bakery with a large selection of pastries and buns. I love, love Chinese buns. These are great quality and you have your pick of fillings to choose from. 

We tried a taro bun, a pineapple and coconut bun, a yam bun and one other I can't remember now. All of them were delicious and fresh. My husband couldn't resist ordering the two for one drinks. He ordered one without sugar. Haha. Of course it came with sugar. They just meant without extra sugar. Just so you know. The nice thing about it was that it wasn't too sweet as they usually are.
author: Nora S.

description:
Been going here once every few months to grab some quick lunch. The food and drinks here are okay, comparable to supermarket packed lunches. My only complaint would be how the baked goods at the deli/display cases aren't kept warm except for the ones at the cashier's counter. Half the time when I'm there to grab a bun or two the goods would always be cold.

And hmm, their Portuguese tarts aren't doing so great lately. It couldn't hold its form and the texture is a little runny. A couple months back it was still good.

Their cold refrigerated stuff are good though. I like their Chocolate Swiss Roll Cakes.
author: Danny Y.

description:
Sighhh.. It sucks that my favorite bread is here but I got treated like shit just yesterday by one of the middle aged ladies that worked there. She probably thought I didn't understand Canto or something but when I was at the register paying for my bread, I heard her mutter something in Canto to one of her co-workers which basically translated to "oh, she's buying all the big ones again" and then stuffing my bread in a paper bag like she was annoyed cause she didn't want to waste a bag on me and that I'm super cheap buying the bigger breads. Are you fucking kidding me? For one, the brioche is my favorite. I also bought this giant, round milk bun cause my little brother doesn't like anything else but this. I just felt so insulted and left pissed off. 

Before paying, there was a younger lady restocking and organizing the bread and she was really nice. I was about to grab one of the milk buns from the front but she offered to help pull the tray out so I can grab one from the back. I was fine with the one in the front but since she offered, I just said okay. After grabbing the one in the back, I realized it did seem kinda sketch. Now I'm wondering if the back ones are the older ones...
author: Stephanie N.

description:
To me, most of the Sheng Kee bakery is all the same, but this one was the one I went to for many years. Lot of selection of breads, rolls, and cakes. The ladies working there seem to be very hasty and sometimes even rude. My mom once told me that the ladies working there would yell at the younger, less tenured people working there in front of all the customers. Very embarassing and not professional at all. In terms of the bread and desserts, very good! I never once had a bad experience getting bread or dessert here. Plenty of seating as well, but the tables can be kind of sticky!

My favorites are the black forest cake, fruit tart, Portuguese tart, milk bread. It's a place to quickly grab a dessert and go home.
author: Carmen C.

description: Do not buy cake from this location. They sell expired cake. We bought one today. It taste terrible. The fruit/strawberry is old probably expired, too. However, pastries and the bread are pretty good. We just won't buy cake from here anymore. Paris Baquette cakes are way better or superior than sheng kee.
author: Deming L.

description:
I just recently found this place with my boyfriend and I am hooked. The pastries are delish and the best part is that you get a free bag and no tax on their food. 
Idk why people are giving a bad review for paying 10 cents for a bag because the bags are free. You live in SF with a plastic bag charge on almost everything from grocery stores to etc. Smh. 
The pictures will be misleading because those pictures are usually fake food looking like the real thing. Most restaurants and fast food places use fake food to take pictures with. 

Anyways, I plan to keep coming back and trying different pastries. 
The service has been good to me as well and I love how they have their own tongs you use instead of all the germs from people's hands.
author: Star S.

description:
This place has long lines, staff are rude, customers even more rude, parking is hell and loud like hell. 

Came here because I didn't want to run across town. There is always a parking problem here. Once in the door there is a line that forms for people paying for their stuff. People behind you will be standing 2 inches behind the other person thinking it makes a difference. At the register, sometimes they will have regulars that are in a rush, cut in line if not the cashier ask what you want in a rude tune.

But what are you going to do if you want a decent birthday cake but don't want to run around.
author: M C.

description:
This place is a newfound discovery in my world, but I'm enjoying it so far. I think the pastries are fairly priced. I come here before work with my guy and we love standing out like sore thumbs amongst the typical crowd that hangs at Sheng Kee. We are always pleased with whatever treats we choose. 

And the cakes are so beautiful! I always want to try one. Maybe one day I will!
author: Mariah O.

description: So many fresh baked goods here! I went around looking 2-3 times at everything because I wanted to get so many things. And everything was so cheap! Ended up with about 8 goodies for less than $15.. awesome! They asked me if I needed a bag which I thought was odd since I didn't think it would be ideal to carry out 8 different little pastries with me, but I said yes. I didn't know they charged for the bags.. 10 cents not a big deal, but they could have just mentioned it at least?  anyway I can't wait to eat all my goodies, the only downside is you're gonna have to eat everything right away before it gets old. Wish I lived closer!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Bought a selection of pastries:
BBQ pork- flaky crust, savory filling
Egg, Ham and cheese sandwich- sweet bread, has mayo, egg over cooked
Custard bun- soft, custard inside
Fried chicken patty sandwich- red sauce ketchup based, chicken was ok, bread was sweet 

BBQ pork bun and custard bun was my favorites. I will be back for more.
author: Jai M.

description:
BF got me the Taro cake for my birthday because he knows it's my favorite, and usually my family buys me this cake every year. 

My family used to always buy the Taro cake in milpitas  & this location's taro cake is just as delicious. They use fresh taro to make the tasty filling  =)

(http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=lUBeAawm2GoJvdW0WeGY9A&userid=NOKodUWSTYVUEpqBRCOfKw)
author: Nicole S.

description:
Cute bakery, I'm addicted to their breads.  I like their breads and eat them for breakfast.  At $2.50 each what a deal.  Their other pastries are okay as well.  Will return for goodies!

UPDATE:  unfortunately their breads have partial hydrogenated junk in it, will have to stop eating it now.  Sad.
author: Eating And Living Well U.

description:
It was pretty chilly so I stopped in for a coffee and ended up leaving with a box full of goodies.

Almond coffee is amazing! Indulged in egg tarts, sponge breads, hot dog buns and angel food cakes. Everything is light, fluffy and very tasty. I will definitely stop by again when I'm in the city.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Cheap. There is seating. On the newer side and clean. They sell boba. 5-10$ card minimum.

Recommend: pineapple bun

Not recommend: taro bun
author: Gee H.

description:
Nice place - with an excellent location. The baked goods are on par with most 'good bakeries.' However, they don't do much to put themselves apart from anyone else. So, it's good, but I want more. The staff, wow, they staff, soooooo helpful and they carry a synergy that makes you feel better. 

I'll come back when I'm in the area and feel like having some regular baked goods. :)
author: Jane E.

description:
Minus 2 stars for horrible staff - rude, seems to hate humankind in general.
Minus 2 stars for questionable hygiene - have seen them drop food and pick it up all casually...
Minus 1 star for overcharging me (on several occasions) because they can't cashier properly.
Plus 1 star for decent pastries. 

Overall, I think I'll stay away which is a pity as I used to go here all the time...
author: Kay D.

description:
Kind of dissapointed... Photos are deceiving. ..

I spent about an hour in traffic to get through SF to get to this place. I was alittle iffy because I read the reviews, but I was just so desperate for bakery goods so I just judged the place by the pictures on yelp. And I was so wrong. All of their baked goods are not fresh and breads are hard and stale. The packaging could be definitely improved. They just gave me a box and stuffed all the pastries in there. No cover seperate plastic sheets for each of the goods. So all of the pastries would be touching and squished on top of another. I asked if they could put it in seperate bags but they just didnt understand me. 

I most likely will not be going back to this place. Sadly.
author: Crystal H.

description:
I'm on the hunt for the best taro breads/rolls and unfortunately, Sheng Kee Bakery did not win this battle. I must admit their selection of various breads, desserts, fresh cakes and taro desserts were very impressive. Would you believe they had four different types of taro desserts?!? This is a taroholic's euphoria! 

First off, they had a taro root bun (not very much taro filling) and a pineapple taro bun which were very similar. Nothing special. Next, the taro twist had little taro paste inside with shredded coconut flakes baked on top. Lastly, was the small taro ball pastry with a surprise mochi inside. Everything was just okay... it didn't meet my expectations compared to my fave in the OC. 

They also had one of my all time favorite: sponge cake but I resisted and dove into the taro desserts because I couldn't find those back home. 

Since I didn't get an opportunity to try the other fancy desserts, I could be missing out but will not know until another visit. One thing I appreciated about this bakery was all the pastries were individually bagged while sitting on the trays. No disgruntle workers here; just lots of standard Chinese baked goods.
author: Santi T.

description:
The last (brief) time I was here to pick up some Portuguese egg tarts, I had completely failed to notice how large this Sheng Kee was. Much larger than the small store-in-the-wall down in Daly City, and probably even larger than the recently renovated Cupertino location.

Their pastries are, as usual, quite tasty, and you're bound to find something you like from among their many, many options. And whatever you get, it helps to toast them first! Compared to their sister locations though, this one does carry a few things I haven't seen at other places, including a much more varied selection of custard-fill pastries. And let's not forget to mention the sales they throw, which is not something I've seen elsewhere: when I was there, they had a buy 4 get 1 free on the BBQ pork puff pastries, and a buy 3 get 1 free on the flaky mochi-filled pastries.

Another big plus is that they take credit cards now too!
author: Johnny W.

description:
Stumbled upon this place after walking around Irving. I shared a hawaiian bun with a friend. It was a bit greasy for my taste. Too much mayo and not enough pineapple!!

I also got a portuguese egg tart since I haven't had one since Hong Kong last summer. They were SO GOOD in Macau.. but that's not the focus here.

The egg tart wasn't the best I've ever had but it was still really good!! The egg part was creamy and really soft, it was semi sweet and the crust was really crunchy. I didn't really see how it was " portuguese " style. I liked that it was still warm when it was served to me. A bit pricy though for an egg tart.. $1.35?

Another pastry I got was the lotus pastry. I was going to splurge and get green tea, black sesame, taro and much more but I ended up just getting black sesame since I wasn't sure if I'd like it. The pastry was good, it was flaky and filled with paste and you could definitely taste the black sesame but one was more than enough. 

Great selection of pastries, but a bit pricey, I feel that you could definitely get similar if not same selections in Chinatown.

P.S. the buns did look relatively good though, I might get some next time I'm around the area.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
I've been going here for years and least once or twice a week. In the past the service and products were AWESOME but now in my onion the service and products haven't been as good. 
The new lady that's the cashier is rude and she always charges me more and when I tell her she just glares at me but CLEARLY it's a hot dog bun and NOT a HK Ham & Egg Bun. How can you confuse those? One is cut down the middle and stuffed with Ham and a wedge of egg, the other isn't! This has happened too many times to me now. I miss the older woman with short hair that used to be there all the time.
Sadly I won't ever be going back for a buns, maybe a cake for someone's birthday but never again for anything else, also the buns have gotten very salty. :(
author: Olivia O.

description:
This is one of the better Sheng Kee Bakeries around the bay.

-It's like a real cafe with coffee and boba (though I'd get my boba elsewhere like Wonderful Foods Co, a block down). And they got plenty of seats and tables for you to rest! It's never full (:
-They always have the pastries you want stocked up. Pineapple buns, taro buns, hot dog buns, custard buns, galore! Did I ever mention how much their pastries are so soft and delicious! Packed full of flavor. 
-What I love most is the TOAST SELECTION here. To die for. Love the Taiwan Toast (though it's pricey for a whole roll... $5.49?), and Coconut Toast. YUM! I always buy some for my family so we can have a quick breakfast. 
-Wide selection of cakes. Never too heavy fruit mousse cakes and fruit cakes. Their cake rolls make a wonderful light dessert or breakfast (green tea roll with red beans!)
-Service is always friendly. I've never had a bad experience with them. Yes, they don't greet you at the door, but they make sure you're in and out of the cash register. Good thing because lines aren't fun when you just want to eat!

Only bad thing is the parking.  Irving Street is so CRAZY. Swear. It's like a mini Chinatown. You can be lucky and find parking on the street (meters) or drive further down the number streets and you can find free residential parking if you don't mind the walk. 

I'd bring cash just in case (lots of banks and atms on Irving so no worries). I know the Sheng Kee at Skyline Plaza takes card now, but it doesn't seem like this one does yet.
author: Joan T.

description:
This is one of my 3 favorite bakeries in San Francisco, especially since it's next to 2 of the best tapioca stores in San Francisco.

I have a sweet tooth so I used to drop $20 every visit when I lived in the SF bay area.

There's usually a lot of choices and even by the end of the day I still find 2 or 3 things left that taste fresh.

There's tables if you want to sit down (I usually get mine to go)

They raised their prices since I was last here but most of the pastries are very inexpensive, affordable and reasonably priced.

The staff always smile and although it can get crowded at some times, people are polite.

Parking can be a pain during the weekday before 6 p.m.
author: Jonah H.

description: Baos and baos, pretty small Sheng Kee area of baos but there are many.  Also they have bobo drinks for 99 cents.  Wow hella cheap, didn't even know until I looked a the receipt.  I have always loved the fake egg and ham bao since I was a kid.  Sheng Kee has a fat ass slice of egg with ham bun.  Sweet.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I am torn because the pastries are really good here. 
However, I took down two stars because every time I go there (more than 20 times now), it smells like wet/dirty rag. A bakery should smell like butter, or at least does not smell like something that reminds you of a wet bathroom. 
I wouldn't say this if it was just one time. But I smell that odor every time I go there, and I do not have a super sensitive nose. 

My suggestion to the store is : Whatever it is, a floor mop, a rag to wipe down the tables, etc, please please be aware that it is really important for a bakery to smell good! Please use disposable wipes or clean rags to wipe off the surfaces/floor!!!
author: Jane M.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery is indeed cleaner than most leading Chinese bakeries. I've tried their sponge cake, pineapple, pineapple custard and cream cheese buns. Their pastries are very delicious and the amount of sweetness is perfect. I like that the sweetness in their pastries are the right amounts. I've been going to Sheng Kee and other Chinese bakeries for so long, I tried pastries from almost every bakery.

I started feeling hungry for something sweet right after coming out of the KFC/Taco Bell restaurant across the street. So I walked across the street to Sheng Kee Bakery and bought myself a Chocolate Cupcake for $1.35 which was very decently priced.

Other than that, I like the Chocolate Cupcake because the amount of chocolate is perfect and it is not super sweet. Every Sheng Kee pastry is light but you'll still get the right amount of sweetness from every bite. Although Sheng Kee pastries tend to be a bit pricier than other Chinese bakeries, but it is still worth the money spent knowing you found the bakery that satisfies your pastry cravings. Oh yeah, I've also tried their moon cakes before and it's very good!

Quick Tip: CASH ONLY
author: Bennett W.

description:
Asian bakeries are the best! I was introduced to this place by my boyfriend, and I can't get enough of the taro pastries. I've searched high and low for my taro baked goods at other bakeries, but it does not compare to this yummie place! The prices are reasonable for the quality and the variety. 
Come early, so you can get the morning selection =)
author: Jemille G.

description:
Geeze I hate the service here. Like every time I come in..I try to tip to see if maybe the cashiers would be nicer to me since I come pretty often..but nope. Crack a smile ladies! C'mon...lol.

The pastries are good, but the service is terrible. It's just so conveniently located for me that I always come in. It's an inexpensive, quick bite to eat and the food items last you until the next day. :P

Cakes are always a go-to for birthdays too. They had really cute ones for Father's day. 
We usually get the Mango Mousse cake.

Things I crave: 
- Chicken PIe
- Canaan(spelling?) toast--bread with butter and sugar basically.

Another thing that's sort of unique: Green tea with mochi pastry. Pretty good--interesting to have mochi inside of a baked good, haven't had that before. 

But seriously cashiers, be nicer to your regulars! -______-. Especially the ones that tip. I've stopped since then because it made no difference.
author: Mariel A.

description:
Grab a pair of tongs, cover your tray with a a piece of wax paper, and pick your favorite Chinese baked goods. My favorites include the blueberry cream cheese danish, pineapple buns, and the coconut bread. The sweet coconut swirls in the bread bring a nice gritty texture! Toasting it makes a quick breakfast to go. They have red bean moon cakes right now!!

Prices range an average of $1.19-$1.89 per danish. It easily adds up when you see all the food behind the glass containers!

Sheng kee also makes great Asian cakes. If you've had them before you know they're lighter and usually contain fruit and only light whipping cream. They're so good :)
author: Samantha L.

description:
As Sheng Kee starts to close, and the clock nears 7pm.. Chinese moms and grandmas line up for the race to grab as many Chinese buns as they can get.  

On your marks, get set, go! Grab those buns!!!

OKAY -- so maybe it's not a race, but it sure can get pretty hectic with all those Chinese ladies grabbing the half-priced buns.  Imagine, an outsider from afar watching these women DUEL to grab as many buns before others can.  It's actually pretty remarkable to see these ladies wait until the magic 7pm time arrives.  This tells you how GOOD their baked goods are.  They're all really delicious.

Well, of Sheng Kee's baked goods, which would I recommend?  I like their taro root bun, their egg custard tart (dan taat), their almond crisp (delicious, buttery goodness! MMM!!!!), and most of their cakes (mango mousse cake is my favorite).  I also like their breads, like their pork soong bread, and any taro-filled breads are EXCELLENT.  

I've been coming to SHENG KEE since I was a kid, and have loved their products for ages, and I'm glad Outer Sunset has this bakery!  It's a staple of Sunset's Chinese community and their fans.  Y'all should try some of their baked goods...better come before 7pm otherwise what you want might be snatched up! :)
author: Matthew L.

description:
I asked if I can get a discount on a bag of bread that is torn in the corner, since I don't like to waste things.  
"No we don't do discounts." Responded the counter lady.  
"but then nobody would buy this." And the bread won't be able to complete its mission to be eaten. 
"Somebody will always buy it" was the response.
Now, I am fine if they would have put a new bag on the bread, or if they said the staff would eat it. Bit this we don't need your business and we don't have to try attitude really irritates me.
I am taking my business elsewhere, and I hope you do too.

edit: right after I put up this review, which isn't even viewable on yelp at this point, I got a message stating that I am just too cheap to pay full price.  I am just including full facts of what happend to me personally, you can decide for yourself what this place think about customer satisfaction and how they respond to customer feedback.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Located down the street from one its sister locations near 9th and 10th on Irving,  this can be a busier Sheng Kee location especially during daylight hours. Sheng Kee is a chain of Hong Kong style bakeries around the Bay Area. Although I think a portion of their baked goods are trucked in, I like the place and more importantly their HK style milk tea. 

This location seems to draw a family-oriented customer base. My personal pastry favorites are the fruit tart as well as the spongecake like cupcake.
author: Paul F.

description:
I come here about twice a week to buy a load of buns for my family's morning breakfast. The buns are of quality and are pretty tasteful. My favorites are the H.K. pineapple buns and the sweet bread. The cakes are delicious and has the right amount of sweetness and taste. It is much lighter than the American cakes and is never overwhelming or too rich for the sensitive taste buds.  The cakes are also creative and beautifully designed yet simple. The desserts are also very yummy with my favorite being the peach cheesecake. I savor the cheesecakes as they are very light, not too rich, and so yummy. 

Sheng Kee is probably the best and well known Asian bakery in the Bay Area.  With a variety of delicious buns, desserts, and cakes they are one stiff competition.
author: Denise W.

description:
11-9-2014 8:00 a.m

Wow, unbelievably horrible service!  Yeah the pastries are pretty tasty, but what happened to me yesterday was pretty ridiculous!  I had driven for an hour and had to pee really bad.  I asked the miserable ugly 21-30 yr old cashier for the restroom key and she gave me a stink eye and asked if I was a customer. Wtf? Duh I pointed to my wife and daughter as they were loading up a tray of goodies.  She says to me "You can get the key after you buy."  Part of me wanted to give her an f-bomb along with a pimp slap but I had to go so bad I didn't want to argue at the time.  I grabbed a pastry and slapped $2 down on the counter.  As she gave me the restroom key I said to her "WOW that is absolutely SHITTY service. I can see why you get bad YELP reviews."  After relieving myself I returned the key and gave her my biggest stink eye ever.  Wifey tried to calm me down, but f-that. I only wish I had taken a pic of this bitch to post up on yelp.  Good news was, the pastries were pretty yummy, and I didn't piss my pants.
author: Jian B.

description:
Great selection of Chinese cakes, mini cakes, and pastries. 
I stop by here on my way to school on some days, and I always find a sweet dessert to have during the day! The staff is great, everything is very dainty and organized. Super sanitary and easy to navigate. 
They have a variety of buns as well such and pork bun, pineapple buns, etc. 
They're prices are ALWAYS cheap, and you're bound to find something in their bakery. They have a huge variety from savory to sweet! I admit the pastries look better than they taste! But dont get me wrong, they're definitely good!
Definitely recommend.
author: Veronica L.

description:
I give them 5 stars for the high turnover, as in really fresh baked buns, danishes and croissant like pastries + I love their light fluffy sponge cake. 

I've been trying all the dim sum and bakery type places in the sunset area. For me Sheng Kee, is all about the pastry. Their coffee is okay if you want to eat your goodies there. But, this bakery is great for bringing home to the house guests something not found in many other places in the US. Garlic croissant twists, pineapple buns, ham & cheese in 4 or 5 different style buns. That furry shredded bacon topping is something I never tried before Chinatown, now I know what it is, I sometimes get that topping on buns here.

Everything I have tried here has been very freshly baked. They refill their boxes of select your own goodies, constantly. There are other American or European style bakeries that rival the pastry they make here, but if you like the white flour, light fluffy, crispy stuff, that is not too sugary most of the time, this is the place.

P.s. If you are sad that there are no twinkies, made anymore. One slice of their sponge cake, though triangle shaped and in 3 or 4 flavors, well :D it's very "twinkiesk" in that way only a little piece of sponge cake can be.
author: Uva D.

description:
The smell is amazing inside! I can't write a good review because we came in looking for moon cakes (which are already prepackaged from an outside vendor), but they are tasty! Cash only -- no tax??

So glad to know this place is just down the block from where I live! I can't wait to venture down there to try something in the future!
author: Leana L.

description:
The place exceeds all over Sheng Kee's I've been to for sure! 

It has your usual pineapple buns, taro buns, ham & cheese croissants, but also MORE -- a way bigger variety of rolls, pastries, and bread. What is a pineapple bun with taro inside? What is a sugar coated toast? Must try you all!

What is It also has a lot of different cakes -- a slice is only $1-$2, not $3-$4 like the one in Richmond (East Bay)!!!!

This place also has a Peet's bar ....that also serves...BOBA. How ridiculously cool is this? 

HOWEVER.....Food review time.

REVIEW: Green tea sponge roll with red bean filling

Sadly, this was just meh. The sponge roll was a bit hard because it was refrigerated. The green tea tasted a bit powdery as if the matcha wasn't mixed in well enough. I didn't like the red bean filling because the red bean was cold/hard because of the refrigeration as well. It just didn't mix/mesh well together. I wished the roll had more cream or something to hold it together since it was just dry overall.
author: Evelyn S.

description:
I have a Sheng-Kee back at home, but since I was visiting SF, I wanted to see if there was a difference in selection in the Bay Area.

There was actually a smaller variety of things to choose from than I thought, and none of it really stood out to me or looked appetizing.

Also, the cashiers seem very uncaring and rude. I had my purse on the counter and she impolitely told me to move it to make room for the food the customer next to me wanted to put down. My bad, but she could have asked nicer. 

While they packed my food, they started squishing all of my goodies in this one box and didn't even care if they cracked or got smooshed inside. It seems that their most important concern was squeezing everything into the least amount of boxes possible.

Furthermore, when I asked for a bag to hold my two boxes filled with treats, the same rude cashier snapped "You have to pay ten cents". I totally forgot about the "paying-for-a-bag" rule, since it doesn't apply everywhere. Okay...you shouldn't even be giving me that attitude when you didn't even offer me the idea of buying a bag when I was purchasing the Asian treats. But by that point, I was fed up with her rudeness and just left unhappily.

Not visiting ever again. And their staff needs to take an anger management class or needs to learn how to respect the human population.
author: Michelle S.

description: Lots of selection. Cheap. What else can you really ask for? This is a good place to go (and any of their other locations, too) if you want a quick (albeit sweet) breakfast for cheap. Otherwise, I'm at Arizmendi.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Good ol' Sheng Kee bakery!

Sheng Kee has always been baking up some wonderful goodies that are great quality - none of that cheap chinatown stuff!

i personally like their hot dog buns and birthday cakes the most - so worth the prices.

i must say though .. their service sucks! But whatever ... i go in to get my goods and i bounce.
author: Kenny L.

description:
Their buns are amazing. I love their pineapple bun ($1.15 each, I believe) and their dinner rolls (around $2 a pack). Texture is perfect for these: soft, with a little give. Sweetness is perfect. 

I tried their boba while they were having their buy-one-boba-for-$1-and-get-another-free promotion. It wasn't memorable.

But definitely go for the buns. :D
author: Tiffany N.

description: $5 minimum for credit cards, just so you're aware. Their stuff is seriously better than the other Sheng Kee's I've frequented. Somehow, it's softer and sweeter here. It also tastes like they might be using real butter. I am a little disappointed they were out of cockatil buns and egg tarts by the end of the day, but I can't really expect much else. Seriously, though, get a giant slab of almond butter toast. Dear lord, it's a heart attack of a slice, but man, it's freaking awesome.
author: Danny C.

description:
I've been coming to this SK since as long as I can remember... 

My favorite pastry from here? Maybe it's more like a cake... The mocha roll! I don't think I've found any other place that makes it quite like them - just enough spongy goodness with a hint of mocha and cream. Yummy.

The bread and pastries here are all worth a try - they also sell small pineapple pastries, mooncakes, etc. Huge variety.

I always get my birthday cakes from here. (: Huge fan of the Japanese Cheesecake! And though I'm not a fan of mango mousse, I actually like their mango mousse cake! Shocking. lol

I think they've started serving Peet's Coffee and making boba drinks! But with such a huge selection in their local area, I haven't gotten around to trying any of their drinks.

The customer service here is what I would call... somewhat typical... not so great but you're only here to pay for stuff - customer service? lol.
author: Susan Y.

description:
Coming to buy a chocolate cake today and when i went home, the label under the cake said that it had expired two days ago....So, this bakery does not throw away expired goods???
Check the expired date everytime you buy something here.
author: IVY D.

description:
Really a 4.5 but what ever, I'm feeling giving. I'm a college student always looking for cheap but worthy food buys (caferteria gets boring). This place is to die for !

Food is GREAT! When heated so I recommend racking up and saving for home heating. I'm just a proper foodie. Bathrooms could be better, they'll learn.
author: Ashana D.

description:
I normally never come in here to buy bao. It's overpriced and it's just normal bao you can get anywhere else in Chinatown for cheaper.

But it was a convenience stop today. And I noticed that they also had buy one get one free bubble tea for $1.99 each! I couldn't pass that up.

I got half a loaf of Taiwanese Toast. One of the ladies was putting new ones out and I wondered aloud if they were warm. She answered me haughtily, saying that it would never be hot because it needs to cool down in order to slice it. Okay. Thanks for the answer...

Anyways, I lined up for the register and even though the line was kind of line, I paid in about a minute. I asked her about the buy one get one free deal, since the menu had some drinks that were actually worth more than $1.99. She said anything was buy one get one free and I was gonna tell her what I wanted when she told me that the milk tea was good. I was like okay, sure, and she proceeded to write it on one cup. And then I was starting to say something else when she said, our taro milk tea is popular too. Well, I was going to get taro milk tea anyways, so it didn't matter... I wasn't planning on getting normal milk tea (I wanted the thai ice tea or the hazelnut flavor), but I didn't mind too much. 

So I got both without ice and waited for like, two minutes. 

I think their system is interesting. They give you a number which is on your receipt and then you show it to them when you get your bubble tea. Now, I also bought something else with that and I normally like to keep the receipts. The lady, who ironically enough, was also the lady who told me the whole "warm bread slicing" concept, was the one to hand me my bubble tea. She crumpled up my receipt and I thanked her. It was nice to hear a thanks back, since that's kind of rare in bubble tea places. 

For the price, the boba wasn't worth it. Technically, it was $1 each. Eh. The milk tea was completely watered down! There needed to be milk, although the tapioca balls were chewy and nice, and it tasted a bit like coffee (which I liked)... Ugh. Watered down bubble tea. Not cool.

I didn't try the taro one (got it for someone else), but from their words: "It doesn't match up to Teaway." I'm assuming it was watery and lacked milk, just like my milk tea.

I'll be back here for bao, and maybe to try another flavored milk tea. Who knows.
author: Nancy C.

description: A wide, interesting array of pastries. They have the right idea but I have to say some of the buns went overboard. I bought the cream coconut bun, both the buttercream and bun were too sweet. I tried the mocha almond cream bun, and same thing - bun and cream were way too sweet. I've had better cream buns in Oakland Chinatown.
author: Briget P.

description:
After going to the one in the south bay I wasn't too impressed with this one. It is still cleaner than the bakeries in Chinatown and tastes about the same. The place does need a bit of a pick me up and they still use the plastic bags here. It makes all the pastries less appealing and the steam from the heat they emit when stuff in the bag softens the texture of many of the items. 

Great place to get cakes from what I noticed.
author: Sarah C.

description:
The Chinese character of "Sheng Kee" means "earn/making a living." In some ways, their wonderful $1.50 for 2 buns deal after 7pm, truly meets the spirit of these two Chinese characters. (Ooops, maybe I should delete this part so I can still get buns after 7pm...)

Although first founded in Taipei, this place doesn't have so much Taiwanese touch in it, but rather with a bit more HK style to me. 

Personally, I like their pineapple buns a lot, taro and red bean flavor are both great. Green onion bun is also pretty good. They have all sorts of toast to choose from. Pretty impressive selections. The multi-grain toast is really healthy and I like it a lot. It's made with nice ingredients and contains with great taste. You can find the English explanation on the little item-name-card for each item on the shelves.
 
As for the pastry part goes, I personally love "Snowballs" the most. It's called "yuki ichigo" in Japanese, which means "snow-strawberry-girl." That's also the reason why I like the strawberry snowball the most. (Mango flavor is pretty good. I personally can't resist berries though..)

Their moon cakes are simply spectacular, I love the tea flavor ones. Oolong tea, jasmine tea, green tea flavors are all great. They have some interesting baked savory items, such as curry beef dumplings and chicken pie, are both popular. As for the two different kind of egg tarts, I prefer Portuguese egg tarts more because it's made with puff pastry. The other kind made with shortcut pastry is good, but not my favorite.
author: Moneta L.

description: They have a wide selection of baked goods and everything is baked fresh daily. I came here because I was looking for the Portuguese egg tarts and they had it! The staff is friendly and I love that they take credit card; alot of Chinese bakeries are cash only which can be inconvenient. They have multiple locations too which is great.
author: Van H.

description:
The baked goods are pretty delicious!

That said, the staff there is down-right rude. The lines are long and parking's hard to find.

The staff treats customers like they are a burden for being in the store. Their system for selling goods is a mess and the staff yells and each other and customers the entire time.
