After we paid for our buns, my girlfriend and I walked out and laughed at how ridiculous this place was.
author: Tyler K.

description: Came here a couple times before and everyone was very sweet and nice. However, the most recent time I went the atmosphere of the bakery was completely changed from what I remember. Once I walked in I could immediately tell there was tension between the workers. The shelves were dirty and there were big dead flies in a couple of counters. I got my bread and sat down with my friends. After about 10 minutes of eating and conversing with my friends, the new Asian short hair lady came over to us and rudely asked if we had boughten something. We replied that we had and she demanded for our receipt. Because we were done with out small bun, we had thrown it away. She told us we had to dig through the trash to find the receipt. Never have I ever experienced such bad service. Probably never coming back here again. The Asian ladies and rude and mean and don't use gloves while handling the food. There are better bakeries elsewhere and in SoCal.
author: Sharon G.

description:
I first experienced Sheng Kee bakery goods while working on an HP running event in Cupertino several years ago.  I can still remember the pineapple bun with the sweet peanut butter filling and the miniature moon cakes with the lotus paste.  Shortly after that visit I found out that Sheng Kee had a location in San Francisco.  I have been a regular customer at this location ever since.

Although I truly miss the peanut butter version of the pineapple bun, I regularly purchase the ones with the custard or red bean paste fillings.  I love the custard bread with raisins, and on more than one occasion I've found myself eating an entire loaf of bread in less than 24 hours.  I like the sliced cake rolls also especially the orange or strawberry ones because they have a different flavor and they're not too sweet.  The super flaky beef curry pastry found inside a hot box near the counter is very good.  This morning I tried the moon-shaped chocolate bun for the first time, and I loved it.  This is without a doubt my favorite Chinese bakery in the City.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
I literally, just this moment, had their almond croissant. OMG, DELICIOUSNESS!
That almond croissant alone deserves four stars, lol.
Overall, I'd probably give 3 stars but DAT ALMOND CROISSANT = 4 stars :)

I've tried their pork sung bun, pineapple bun, bbq pork bun, cream cheese bun and egg tart. They're all average-tasting. Hubby and I both like Sunset bakery's pineapple bun a lot better.

The boba milk tea isn't bad if you're really craving it.
Maybe a bit sweet, and I'm a person who loves me some sugar.
author: Lauren L.

description:
MMMM!!! I LOVE WARM BREAD!
I literally touched all the bread to make sure to buy the warmest one. The housemate chose a warm red bean bread, and I ended up choosing another warm one, forgot what it was called, but it had an interesting center - I wasn't really feelin' it though. I also grabbed a taro vitasoy that totaled up to around $3-4ish. The environment was nice and fun to chat in, but I definitely had yummier (and cheaper) bows elsewhere. Overall, I'll give them a B+!
author: Linda K.

description:
Food - 3.5
Service - 3
Atmosphere - 3

Overall - 3

If I wrote this review 4 years ago, it would probably be an easy 4 stars. But there have been so many changes to this franchise and the quality of it's bread that I give it a lowly 3.

For one, the quality of the food has dropped tremendously. The raisin custard buns are less crispy, the sugar seemingly more saturated. The onion breads are less onion and less bread. Almost every single item on the menu has fallen in size, and uses a ridiculously low amount of toppings it's stupid. It really is.

The prices have risen. Kind of ridiculous as well. That enough merits the lowering of overall stars.

The only positive is the consistency of the heated pastries (normally located by the register) namely the curry horn, bbq pastry, and chicken pie. All still delicious, and even with the price risen I would still spend the money on it.

Would I come back? Yes, for my childhood. Do I buy many of the breads anymore? Never.
author: Dion W.

description:
The pastries , cakes, buns, breads are great! The customer service ok. but that's kind of expected for this place right? Um.

Lots of variety.
author: Veranna N.

description:
Like 85 degrees but not. Really good cakes. One of the few places in the city that I get cakes from. I love that they have sun cookies (flat flaky pastry filled with sweet yellow lotus seed paste), but the pastry part wasn't as good as I hoped. The pastry was really good in the melon cookie (same concept but with melon filling), so I may have just had a bad batch of sun cookies. 

Overall, good pastries, fun to try all the different kinds. Very good cakes.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
You're no 85 Degrees, but your buns still melt in my mouth and cause great waves of pleasure to cascade through my body.  

Your custard buns are heavenly, taro buns divine, your hawaiian buns are best HOT out of the oven..and your custard bread can be eaten alllll dayyy long.

I'm not a bigggg fan of your on tots...best get those in china town, but the buns the buns....I can't get over your buns.
author: Aly A.

description: I don't know if it was one of those days where I was so hungry I can eat a cow or that this place has the best pastry I've ever had. It was not only delish but also price friendly. My favorite is the milk bun and brioche! The coconut bun was good, too, bun the red bean was just ok. I'm from Sacramento, wish they had that kind of goodies here. I'm sitting craving the brioche!!!
author: Samira M.

description:
The last time I was here was in high school.  Goes to show that I don't get around in Irving much.  However, I practically ran over to buy a drink at this place after my horrible lunch at King of Won Ton.  Bought a slice of chocolate roll, apple turnover and a chocolate/vanilla square cake for the family to nosh on.  

The cakes were very chocolately which is rare for Chinese bakeries because they usually look semi-brown.  I really liked the flavor of the cake and it was fresh too!  DH said the apple turnover was excellent.

Bought a whole chocolate roll to take home.  That was $5.  What a deal considering some places in Chinatown charge more.

Will consider gettting birthday cakes here!
author: Wendy H.

description:
I often miss Sheng Kee when I'm in socal-- I love their shredded pork buns, ham/egg/cucumbers bun, dan tats (custard tarts) and basically everything! I don't think I've ever purchased something and didn't love it!

While I'm super excited about 85 degrees here in Irvine, I still have to say, it's no Sheng Kee! Sheng Kee cakes tramples all over 85 for SURE! Like I said, almost everything is good in here! Perfect for breakfast, snack or even a light lunch!
author: Tiffany U.

description:
I really like their pineapple buns and the yellow swirl sponge cake. It's so delicious and you know its fresh too! 

The Mango Moose cake it yummy too! So is the fruit tart! 
Call in 24-28 hours in advance if you want to change up your fruits in the fruit tart.
author: Jess W.

description:
Loved it!

I saw a great and extensive selection of cakes and pastries. Too bad I couldn't try it all! We purchased a strawberry mousse cake for a family dinner. It was my first time having a mousse cake, and it was nice and light. There were peaches, kiwi, and strawberries on top, it made the dessert feel a little healthier. The cake reminded me of a sponge cake. It's hard to find these bakeries in San Jose.
author: Camery V.

description:
Sheng Kee is a necessary evil. Why is it evil? For a Chinese bakery, it's not that great. Why is it necessary? Cause sometimes I'm in the area and I need a quick bite, and nothing fits the bill for an in-between-meal snack like a cha siu bow.

In fact I get my hair cut around here, which means I get here after my long ass commute, before getting home for dinner, but already a little famished.

Once a month. Same routine.

And there are the other places I stop by, Walgreens, Wonderful Foods, etc. But in the case of those places, it's either necessities or boba, respectively.

And then there's cha siu bow at Sheng Kee. I guess that's better than the taco supreme at Taco Bell.
author: Tony L.

description:
I believe this place bakes rainbows and happiness into their pastries.  I Love me a good Chinese bakery, and this place takes it to another level.  The selection of buns and pastries is huge, and range from sweet to savory.  While its not a cheap as a lot of other bakeries, all of their items are so flipping yummy that you wont hear me complaining.  

Their cakes are stunning - hopefully I will have a good occasion where I can try one soon.  

If you want a truly incredible snack - try the cream cheese bun!
author: Virginia B.

description:
I like getting Almond Croissants ($1.89) here. I also liked their milk tea actually (regular or almond), although the almond milk tea is very sweet.

I would not recommend the weird croissants like green tea mochi.
author: Derek M.

description:
Forget Safeway cakes for your kid's birthday. You won't find any neon yellow overly sweet icing on Sheng Kee cakes because they're light, tasty, and just plain wonderful.

They also offer pastries and rolls. Try any of the following and you won't be disappointed: black forest cake, strawberry mousse cake, chocolate roll, red bean green tea roll, taro toast, fruit tart, pineapple bun, egg custard tart, almond cookies, ham and onion pastry..I could go on and on!

Sheng Kee is spacious with lots of seating, clean, comfortable, open early, and very affordable. Take a friend here, load up on goodies, and then sample each other's..but don't fight over the food!
author: Patty L.

description:
"Asian pastries that white people love"

Overpriced for what it is, quality is pretty average all around. Nice variety, but I'm not a fan of over half their inventory. Their more traditional chinese pastries are ok, overall a bit too sweet for my palette, but it does not surprise me that they would make their items on the sweeter side.  

Their fruit cakes are terrible. I don't know why people love that crap, there's too much damn cream, the actual cake is pretty delicious but the ratio of low quality cream and canned fruit outnumbers the cake in like a 10 to 1 ratio. Maybe people think that cake is more healthy because there's so much fruit? It's garbage. You want fruit, eat a pie. If you gotta have their overpriced cakes, go for the ones with the taro or walnut cream fillings. Those fillings are actually pretty good. Not mango though, that is pretty disgusting. Mango cream? Who came up with that idea?  It's bad.  I don't even know if they have chocolate cake because nobody ever buys any other cake from this place other than that goddamn fruit cake.
author: Wes C.

description:
Founded in Taiwan, Sheng Kee is now in most major metropolitan areas in California.  For the most part, they're surprisingly consistent from store to store.  It's a good reliable place to get Chinese pastries and Sinicized western cakes.

Some of my favorites are their sweet buns filled with taro, coconut, custard, or cream (Chinese interpretation of the Mexican Pan Dulce), Portuguese Egg Tart which is similar to an egg tart but caramelized (served warm), Curry Pastry Puffs which is really good here (served warm), moon cakes and various traditional Chinese pastry.  Their Asianized cakes are pretty good as well.  They're generally not as sweet, use more whipped cream rather than frosting and are airier than their Western counterparts.
author: Paul K.

description: I like this Taiwan style bakery.  Great selection, friendly staff and reasonable prices.  I lived in Shanghai for eight years and there were many similar style bakeries there...Sheng Kee is very much like them.  If you like your baked goods with a "slightly less sugary" take than our local SF bakeries (and I do, though I'm a born and bred San Franciscan) you can't go wrong with Sheng Kee!
author: Matt D.

description: This place has been my go-to bakery fahevuh. Super cheap, quality Hong Kong style buns, pastry rolls, muffins, etc. Best part is the cakes, which are truly excellent, especially the mango and chocolate ones. Well worth a trip across the city if you're on the Bay side of things. $2 for a super flaky, fresh baked apple turnover? I'm there.
author: Nick C.

description: I was pleasantly surprised on how yummy everything was.  I bought about $10 worth of pastries and for some reason I had a craving for taro so I picked almost everything taro.  The custard bun was also delicious and will definitely grab more of those next time.  The Dan tat's did not travel well and were mushy by the time I got home.
author: Rosalind S.

description: Stocked daily so get here early if you don't want to miss out on your favorites.
author: Matt H.

description:
Yes, CLEANER than most, to quote Bennett W.  -and, A BAKERY FOR ALL SEASONS.

Step to the self serve lucite pastry bins, directly left of the entrance, like jewels in their respective showcases.  -then, U around to the small case, past the bottled soft drinks, past the assorted sliced breads and baguettes,  heating filled savory crescents  by the cashier's counter. 

 You will see the French pastries directly ahead when entering, in the chill case beckoning you with colorfully decorated pieces of sugary delights in all shapes & sizes.  

There is seating for patrons who want to imbibe their treats immediately.  Coffee & tea and soft drinks are also available.  -needless to say, catering to an appreciative international  neighborhood.

It could easily become a daily habit!
author: Clifford L.

description: I've tried Sheng Kee Bakery's cakes a couple of times and they are perfect for elderly Asian folks. My relatives such as my grandparents, aunts, and uncles would always say everything is too sweet, but not the cakes from here! I ordered the Black Forrest Cake for my dad's birthday dinner. Everyone loved it and said it was just right for their taste buds. This is the to go spot if you want to please your elders. This cake was light and fluffy and not sweet at all so I knew the older relatives would like it.
author: Anji W.

description:
To be honest, 85 degrees beats this place's butt. 

Moon cakes were pretty good. I miss the ones I get from home, but the small ones are a bit pricy, but they're definitely good. I tried the red bean one and the pineapple one and good.

Pineapple buns were pretty good. I got the one with custard and it makes a huge mess, but ya know, it's a pineapple bun. if you can't get that right, then there are big problems.

The hot dog and cheese bun (which is a fave of the bf) is pretty good. I don't love the cheese in a bun, but it was decent. 

It brings me back home to socal where these baked goods are everywhere and it's nice to be reminded of it.
author: Nina Y.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded up.  

I was walking past here tonight on my way to dinner and got distracted.

For good reason too.  

Because starting at 7pm, all the little bun items are 50% off!  

Me = Chinese = the most frugal of all the Asians = sales make me HAPPY.

Come here at 6:40pm to get the goods.  Around 7pm, most of the good stuff is gone.  The trick, perfected by the many Asian mommas, papas, and grandmommas and grandpapas, is to come at 6:40pm, grab your desired buns, and then just stand around and wait until 7pm to pay for your food.  Very Asian, I know.  

They have all your standard buns that you'd find in a nicer Chinese bakery: red bean, green onion, hot dog and green onion, pineapple buns (and, as the sign clarifies, "pineapple look alike crust, no pineapple inside." LAWL.), taro buns, custard buns, and much more.  I like the red bean ones as well as the corn-ham-mayo-grease ones.  DELICIOUS.  They also have cakes (MANGA MOUSSE FTW), perfect for birthdays or any other occasion.  

I only bought 2 buns tonight, but the Chinese momma next to me was piling dozens and dozens of buns on her tray.

I was like DAYAM, WOMAN.  

She explained to me while we were in line that it wasn't all for her.  It was for her eight children.

Right.  Right.  Chinese mommas don't have eight children.  

Anyway, I'll admit. . .I was actually pretty tempted to load up on more, but I overheard one Chinese momma say, as she was inspecting the buns carefully, "Zhen de bu jian kang!!"  which roughly translates to "This is really unhealthy!!"  

And then I looked at the buns, saw the grease, and decided that two would be enough.

For now.

But anyway, this place is otherwise awesome and authentic.  And it's on Irving Street; you can't get anymore authentic than Irving.  

I'm talking about everything west of 19th avenue aka Asian-side-Irving. 

This place only loses 1.5 stars because it is FREAKING EXPENSIVE for an Asian bakery.

Okay, so you might come in, notice that all the buns are like $1.50 and be like, Vivian C. what are you talking about?

Uh. . .well, if you know anything about Chinese bakeries, you'd realize that anything over $1.00 is LE EXPENSIVES.  Their chicken pies are $1.50.  WUT.  Chicken pies should go for roughly 80 cents.  

But whatevs, it's still cheaper compared to everything else in this city, so you still come out with a good deal.  So, it's all good.

I love my Chinese bakeries. JIA YOU*, Chinese bakery!

*JIA YOU = pretty much Chinese version of FTW
author: Vivian C.

description:
3.5 Stars.

Love the HK Style Chestnut Cake!! Light, airy cake packed with a thick layer of chestnut bits/paste, and topped with fresh fruit. YUM! The presentation looks very nice also. Definitely reminds me of those bakeries in HK. However, it can be kind of pricey since a 6-8" cake can be ~$30. But I think it's worth it :) However, if I'm not ordering a chestnut cake, I would choose Schuberts (in the Richmond) over Sheng Kee.
author: Michelle L.

description:
hmm...it's just like the description after the rating..."A-OK'.  Nothing that really excites me.  The place seems clean but my pineapple custard bun doesn't look like those i remember eating as a kid.  Maybe this is now the cool way of making them and I'm just outdated.  A good pineapple bun to me has a nice thick layer of that crunchy stuff on top.  The only one that resembles pineapple buns from my childhood were the regular ones. Meh.  I want the custard.

The cocktail bun was good.  I ate it the day after I bought it, had it in the sealed baggy but it was kinda dried out already.  Still, the inside is yummy.  The "old lady" cookie is good too...not too sweet and the filling had the right amount of chew with the extra flakey outsides...i bet a ton of shortening was used.

SK isn't mind blowing, but if I'm ever in the neighborhood i'll stop by for sure.
author: Sally T.

description:
Sheng Kee has been one of my favorite since I was a kid and this one was not a disappointment! I got the wheat bread which is so gooood. I love how their thick toast and so soft.. I also got the shredded pork bun for my brother which we pretty much grew up eating.  They have such a huge selections of pastries and buns.  They're fresh and you can never go wrong with that. 

Their service is very friendly and there's a seating area too so you can enjoy it there.  

Honestly, Irving is the street to be for good food.  Sheng Kee's really convenient too because there's a bank either on the same block or one down and the only downfall is probably parking but sometimes you get lucky with the residential areas.
author: Lisa L.

description: Sheng Kee always does me right! Today I had the potato salad sandwich and a cup of coffee. It set me back a whopping $3.76. Thanks Sheng Kee.
author: Adam H.

description: Asian bakery is all there is to say. If you want asian breads or snacks you can get it here. Occasionally buy cakes from here and they can be pretty pricey....bought a cake for my grandpa's birthday and it was $24 bucks... Not such a big deal but the cake is only about 8in? maybe 10? I would have rather bought a cake from safeway.
author: Alex T.

description:
Decided to stop by Sheng Kee this morning just for a quick and inexpensive breakfast.  Probably not the most healthy meal, but I went with the egg custard tart (not the "Portuguese-style" one) and the pineapple bun with coconut. The pastries all range from about $1.35- maybe $2.

Service: No line or hardly any wait at all at 9:00 in the morning.  To the point, and you're in and out.  Simple.

Food:  Both the pineapple bun and the egg tart were soft, flaky and light--good textures.  The coconut paste in the pineapple bun had a subtle flavor and not too sweet, which I liked.  As for the egg tart (dan tat), it wasn't anything overly amazing, but I definitely have no complaints.

Verdict: Sheng Kee is pretty good if you're in Irving--tasty, quick, and cheap.  Although, if I had some extra time, I'd walk the 5-8 minutes up to Sunset Bakery for the baos and other pastries or head down to Golden Gate Bakery in Chinatown for their egg tarts. Mmm.  You get a good deal, but there are definitely some other reaaally good options in SF.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Pastries/buns - average
Cakes - yum, above average
Variety - good

I like to come here predominantly for the cakes. I'll come for the pastries if I'm in a bind, but otherwise I'll get them for bakeries in Oakland Chinatown which I think taste better. This SKB has pastries/buns, cakes, sandwiches, dessert rolls, beverages, snacks like mochi and small moon cakes, dan tat (egg tarts), and a couple hot items kind of like little Asian hot pockets in the morning and midday.

Decent place... tables aren't the cleanest. Parking is street and metered. Pay the 25 cents/ 9min. It's worth it. I see lots of parking enforcement along Irving and they are not shy to give tickets.
author: Jenn D.

description:
It's okay. The thin almond cookies are good.

There is an asshole who works here who needs to take customer service 101.
author: Erica A.

description:
Love love love Sheng Kee! I grew up eating Sheng Kee since i was in elementary school and now that I have gone to college I tell EVERYONE about it. I use to always get their Coconut bun, but now they have cut down the size and amount of coconut on it I would recommend my coconut lovers the Pineapple Coconut Bun. They put wayyy more filling inside and it's much softer. 
Also, a couple of my stable picks are, the Pineapple.. custard and red bean buns! Another good quick breakfast food are the rolls they have on the bottom display.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Sheng Kee's a chain bakery that's popped up in quite a few places. They sell a great selection of baked Asian good ranging from hotdog buns to cakes. The prices aren't cheap as the mom and pop bakery shops around various places. Their overall quality of parties and cakes are average.

One lame thing about the Sheng Kee is they store their pastries in room temperature plastic boxes. There's nothing like a good warm pastry.

The overall quality of their pastries are mass produced tasting quality. There isn't that special something that a mom and pop bakery puts into their pastry. There's a few things that stand out over the rest. Their thick sliced bread are good. The cheese hotdog buns are tasty.

The cakes are better looking than the plain supermarket cakes and they taste better overall. It's more asian like cakes here with all the fruits compared to other traditional ones with creme and jelly.

Overall, Sheng Kee makes some decent quality pastries and cakes. They don't have the quality compared to small places.
author: Steven B.

description:
This store does not abide by the saying "The customer is alwasy right."  Last week, I went in to purchase my 99 cent Thai Iced Tea.  The girl behind the counter did not put ice in my drink.  I'm American, we like our ice.  I asked for ice and she basically refused to provide me any. "Oh, it's cold enough." I then proceed to ask for my money back if they can't provide me ice.  It took seriously three minutes to resolve.  I receive another Thai ICED tea, bu tthis time with ICE, but I had to fight for it.

I'm not going back there again.  They can kiss my ICED ass.
author: Jean A.

description:
My family has a long history with Sheng Kee.  When we lived in Sacramento, we would always visit this bakery when we visited the Bay Area to buy the next week's breakfast.  But for some reason we stopped doing that & I think I know why now.  The boyfriend & I decided to grab some ready'set breakfast since we both have to get to work so early.

The Pineapple bun was completely hollow on the inside.  Although the top was crispy, it was nothing special.  The Pineapple custard bun was like the regular pineapple bun but it was just filled with not a lot of mediocre custard.  The Cocktail bun was tough  & the filling was way too sweet.  The BBQ pork bun was mediocre @ best.  The Hot dog cheese bun - one of my favorite things to eat - was super salty & the cheese did nothing.  Finally the Curry beef horn.  The pastry was thick & therefore tasted raw & the filling did not have a lot of flavor.

The food was all nicely packaged & the store is really clean.  Unfortunately all of that doesn't matter when the food is just par & the prices are high compared to the many bakeries that exist in the immediate vicinity.
author: Karen S.

description: Hands down my fave bakery in SF. Popped by here for a bakery snack on my way for a long drive. Ended up trying several things: chocolate croissant, BBQ baked bun, garlic bread, chicken pie, beef curry horn.... And I can't wait to come back and try everything else. Extra fresh. Extra flaky. Extra tasty. :)
author: Judi B.

description:
I'm a sucker when it comes to baked goods in individually wrapped bags. Sheng Kee has an assortment of yummy buns and pastry all nicely put together in clear-view wraps. The red bean buns and raisin bread are my faves. And all of their delectables are freshly baked DAILY!

Parking is a beeyatch in the Sunset District so head over to WestLake Shopping Center instead.
author: Dee T.

description: This was a simple stop we made while visiting SF.  the selection here is pretty good.   Pretty straight forward place.   The goods were tasty and the Taro boa was nice.  Check this place out.
author: Mo m.

description:
I'm not sure what the hype about 85 degree bakery is in SOCAL. I went to college in Irvine and when 85 opened up, I was like... this is just like Sheng Kee from Frisco where I grew up except there a super amount of people in line all the time.

Sheng Kee is what I grew up with and to me it's always better than 85. The taro bread and the custard bread here are super good. My family always loves to get our cakes from here, with the super nice looking mango (and tasting) fruit cakes being the favorite, while sometimes we stray and get the taro or something else.

Delicious
author: Wilson T.

description: Disgusting. Tried 9 different mini cakes at a dinner party. Shared them all and threw them in the trash after 1 bite. 9 people brushing their teeth and using listerine to rid the taste. Unfortunately the memory stays.
author: Marina D.

description:
Mien Bao?  Bread?  Dahn Go? Cake? Beng? Cookie?  yes, they got it all.  All in that nice little shop with the glass panels and plastic wrapped individual pastries.  I've been coming here once in a while, mainly for the cakes and tarts that come out of this wonderful shop.

I absolutely like their Fruit tart as it is such an eye pleaser and taste bud pleaser too!

Last night, I came here to get a cake for my mom's birthday.  And being the picky person she is, no cheese, nothing too sweet, nothing chocolate or coffee, nothing too tart, and some other ones I can't remember.

But the great thing about them is that their cakes are not only delicious but I was able to find one that met all my mom's desire.  They had a Mango Kiwi mousse that looked hella good, and tasted good too.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pWVSjwLLjclFGWmhkqsWLw?select=cTkhSx7oVZv2ikgypUWRhQ 

I was even tempted to grab a hotdog cheese bun as a snack, it was alright.  maybe if i heated it up, it woulda tasted better.
author: Vincent K.

description:
When I first came here, I was amazed at all the differest kinds of pineapple buns.  Seriously, there's coconut, taro, custard, chocolate...and of course, original and HK-style original (apparently there's a difference).  I've had all of them, and like snowflakes, they're each original and unique.  Having said that, given the amount of cholesterol in these things (the topping is made of egg yolks plus sugar), perhaps these are best as a once in a while thing instead of a regular habit...thing.  Anyway, for a really interesting pineapple bun experience, try toasting these (especially the taro and chocolate ones)...they get all crunchy on the outside, but the filling gets nice and gooey.  Yum!

Moving on to the other buns, I've had 
- the taro twist (a personal favorite; wonderfully mild flavor...eat 'em hot), 
- the coconut twist thing (also delicious and also not that healthy)
- bbq pork bun (i've had better..and cheaper)
- red bean bun and taro bun (see bbq pork bun)
- moon shaped chocolate bun: unique.  I can't say I've ever encountered a bun quite like this one and I'm still not sure what they were going for with the Mexican bun crust plus the super sweet chocolate inside.  Still, I've had it more than once, so I guess it works on some irresistible level.
- vietnamese sandwiches: the ones at irving cafe & deli down the street are better, plus I bit into a jalapeno and my mouth went numb for an hour...

Some other reviewers have mentioned that this place is pricey, and it is (in fact, their prices have gone up recently).  Plus, they no longer have the special $1.50 for any two buns after 7:00 pm thing (I once saw an old Asian woman knock a plastic tray full of buns out of another old Asian lady's hands...intentionally).  I'd say those two things have knocked them down a notch in my book, but as was mentioned before, this really is the only nicer Asian bakery in Richmond/Sunset, so if you're looking for a higher caliber of bun, this is it.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: We really have enjoyed this place. Very tasty buns and cakes. Everything seems to be made fresh on site. Wish they had even more selection. Also like how there is an area in the back where you can sit and enjoy a bun with a coffee.
author: Brian H.

description: this is my favorite spot for getting milk tea. $1.6 a cup.  much cheaper than cafe bakery, ABC or most places.  And you don't need to add sugar because it is ready to drink already with cream and sugar.  The sales ladies are all very nice!  i love this place.  Thank you!
author: D F.

description:
Out of all the madness getting in and through San Francisco, this bakery was pure joy. Coming from the SGV into Bay Area was a complete turn-around for me and I was so confused by the way everything worked and how people even got to places.. it looks like hell. (First time!) Every where we drove, we were lost and confused. This place made me feel home, and their bread is just as good as it looks and the pricing is decent.

Also a plus because their store wasn't as tiny as the neighboring "restaurants"
author: Cinpy C.

description:
The cream puffs are amazing. They're kind of like a filled egg pudding or something like that. They're my favs. The palmiers are among the best I've had.

Vegetarians, beware! I bought several yummy goods here for years... then they started labeling the ingredients and I saw that my favorite tart had LARD in it. Yes, LARD.

That aside, the desserts are just fabulous.... just read the ingredients before you stuff your pie hole.
author: Amelia D.

description: This place is adorable, seems to make the food fresh, and has a huuuuge selection. I recommend practically everything with cheese on it. All their buns and savory foods are delicious and very cheap!
author: Cecilia A.

description:
We stopped by to pick up a few of our fav Chinese baked goods.....we bought the custard filled bread loaf, Hong Kong pineapple bun, custard filled pineapple bun and a taro filled pineapple bun....

The custard bread is so yummy....freshly baked Hawaiian sweet bread with layers of custard..........we ate the whole loaf in a few minutes.

The pineapple buns.....so many different types and fillings, so fresh and sweet....and all so good.  Plus...they are all wrapped individually  to insure freshness and ease of eating neatly.

For a few bucks......my sweet tooth and hunger pains were gone!
author: Raider J.

description:
Expensive!!! they asking high price for a bun. 
Taste just like so so, but no surprise.
By the way, they are not offer buy one get one promotion any more.
author: SteveMorris M.

description:
The pastries here are hit or miss.  

The hits are true hits:
-the almond croissants - super almondy, great flakiness to the croissant
-curry puffs - these are so delicious when warm

The things that I've tried and haven't liked at all:
-the taro pastry - looked promising wearing it's nifty plastic baggy, but when I tore into it I discovered it tasted like turd.  Maybe I'm just spoiled by the one's at 85 degrees C, those taste like heaven when you bite into them
-the brown sugar cake - this one looked like a turd, but i decided not to be judgemental.  i should've been, it tasted as it looked.

A couple other things I picked up but haven't tried yet:
-egg custard tart
-portuguese style egg custard tart
-i didn't pick up any cakes but I just wanted to mention how pretty the cakes looked, will definitely try some the next time i'm there

I have about 100 g more of processed sugar in me now than before I went to Sheng Kee.  I think the sugar low is about to hit, means its about time to take an afternoon nap.
author: Vivian L.

description:
clean. decently priced.
I just picked up an 8 inch strawberry mousse cake for my youngest brother's birthday.
the thing with Chinese cakes is this: you must remember that the frosting is always much lighter and more airy than your traditional American cakes. 

I normally don't like frosting on Chinese cakes, I just can't stand the white cream or the way the cream they use to make flowers tastes. 

SHENG KEE FROSTING IS DIFFERENT! 

It's so damn good... I enjoy it. It's not TOO sweet which and it is never too rich. 

Their other pastries are good too. Custard bread is one of my favorites, I used to just eat a few slices for breakfast...

I miss the days when one of my uncles worked here. My family freaking grew up on Sheng Kee pastries..
author: Susy C.

description:
CAKES CAKES CAKES!! ...and pastries.

The cakes look beautiful and taste amazing. One of my good friend got me a green tea mousse cake with red bean filling for my 18th birthday. It was not exactly the best tasting cake, but it was still pretty good. The taste of green tea was potent but the filling was sweet, so it counterbalanced the bitter taste of the green tea. The mousse cake was light and fluffy - perhaps too light and fluffy. I prefer my cakes to be a little richer and denser.

I say go for the chocolate cakes and you won't be disappointed! The fruit tarts are a winner, too.
author: Annie S.

description: That is one of my favorite bakery, everytime when I wake up late, I will go sheng kee to buy breakfast before work, but I only buy sandwich, because their bun kind a expensive. I also love their cake especially tiramisu and the cheese cake, eat them all the time! Yummy!!
author: Emily W.

description: This place is delightful. The cakes are nice and soft and their $1 tapioca drinks are tasty. The only issue I have with this shop is the conditions of their eating area, the tables are dirty and the couch/booth is worn out and ripped.
author: Riko H.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery has delicious pastries! They have such a variety of different buns and breads and cookies. They have sweet to salty, lunch to dessert, and chinese to american styled pastries. 

Their loaves of breads are oh so tasty - my favorite is the coconut and custard bread. It is soo buttery, and soft , compared to American styled bread which is coarse.

They also have light, fruity cakes for birthdays and you can order there or pre order. The prices are a little high for these pastries and cakes but you get what you pay for. I come by and buy a bunch to bring home to my family and friends if I am around the area!
author: Alice T.

description:
Everything's overpriced and they don't have any signature items. Their pastries and breads all have a really rough texture and are chewy. Their cakes are fine though. I especially enjoyed the chestnut cake and the Japanese cheesecake.

Sheng Kee is like the ONLY upper-scale Asian bakery chain in SF and that's not a good thing. It'd be good to have more competition since they pretty much have a monopoly. COME TO SF, KEE WAH BAKERY!!!
author: Cheri S.

description:
Vanilla or chocolate?

Both. As a sponge cake. With a layer of cream between the two halves.

Buck in price. Much more in taste.

Impossible?

Sheng Kee makes dessert fantasies come true.
author: Jason B.

description: Sheng Kee offers walls of unique savory and sweet exotic flavored pastries baked on site AND they offer Peet's coffee. I prefer the low budget pineapple bun. No pineapple included; simply a sugar criss-cross pattern on top of a croissant-soft bun.
author: Carrie H.

description:
Sheng Kee on Irving is old school.  I used to come here a lot when I used to stay in the avenues.  I actually have one on my side of the bridge but for some reason I prefer or only come to the Irving location.

Ultimate fave: Moon-shaped Chocolate bun!!!  It's the same concept of a chocolate croissant but taste way better.  The bun is sweet like a Pan de Sal or madeline, topped with flakes of chocolate and filled with even more chocolate goodness. Take a bite of a freshly made one or microwave for 10 sec....it will not disappoint. 

Pork Buns are OK but I really enjoy the hot dog/cheese buns and the cream cheese buns. They're so good, esp when fresh and warm. I haven't tried the Strawberry Stick but the hubby loves it!! Mango Mousse cake is also pretty good.

When in the area, I always try and stop by to bring some treats back home.
author: Resa N.

description: The buns are a little on the pricier side, however they're still yummy. What's so nice is that everything is individually wrapped so it's nice as a housewarming gifts to people, or just good to package for on the go. I think they've changed their recipe the past few years because the buns don't last as long as they use to. Also I think they're more chewy now too. Regardless still yummsies!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Walking into Sheng Kee Bakery is like walking into Japan for me; okay, so I am well aware that Sheng Kee is Taiwanese, not Japanese, but that's beside the fact. Asian bakeries in general evoke a sense of nostalgia for me as I find myself feeling a little "homesick" for Japan and the pan-ya there.

Sheng Kee is the next best thing though--I love looking at the displays of breads, moon cakes, etc. Their regular cake selection is also enticing up front, along with the mochi rolls. Mmm! Prices aren't so bad either, for example:

Cheese Hot Dog Bun: $1.09
*BIG* Egg Custard: $1.25

Oh, their egg custards are wonderful when they're fresh and un-burnt. My parents bought a slew of the egg custards here once and my sisters and I...well, we decided we would eat at least one, if not two, or more...they were quite delicious.

There's seating in the bakery for chit-chat or a little reading/relaxing. I like to see myself coming here more for that last part, since so far I've only popped in to grab a few breads to-go. 

Next, I'll have to try the cakes.
author: Helene K.

description:
No complaints about their bread, except that I always get greedy and buy too much, then I can't finish it. I love the salty ones, like the ham and corn one... love it... but also like the traditional pineapple bun and the cupcakes they have by the cash register.

The prices I think are aiite, just like any other Sheng Kee really, and if you wait for the 7pm deal, just be ready to grab whatever the hell you can, no time to be picky!
author: Daphne L.

description:
Sheng Kee have a great selection of pastries and cakes! I love their coconut and raisin loaf bread! its really to die for to me! i always over purchase every time i step food into Sheng Kee. They have a variety of cakes you can purchase or you can special order one as well. 

If only there was a Sheng Kee by my house i will go there few times a week to stock up!
author: Jenny G.

description:
This is my jammm. Freshest asian bakery - everything is still steaming out of the ovens - ANY time I go in. No joke. I can't get enough: 

BBQ Pork Buns (SO FRESH)
Custard / Creamcheese Buns
Vanilla Spiral Cake (always on sale)
Almond Cookies
Sweet Bread (always still warm)
author: Monalisa M.

description: Awesome Chinese bakery that is also super cheap. An awesome place for a $2.99 lunch (small pasty + drink). There's also always a bunch of old people just lounging about which adds a sense of authenticity to the place. Feels like China cuz that's what old folk do.
author: Paul B.

description: I was craving either a red bean cake or a mooncake so I figured that if any shop was bound to have it, this one would have it. Of course they did -- and they had a bunch of flavours too. I grabbed a mooncake and a red bean cake (and then got them mixed up in the bag and somehow managed to pull the right one). The mooncake was super tasty which satiated that craving quite quickly.
author: Shauna S.

description: I love this place , haven't been here in awhile but I love the food here ,it always fresh never Burt or anyless,
author: Seaera T.

description: Fantastic price for a delicious array of baked goods! A neat place to stop by for a quick breakfast, and a great fusion of East meets West.
author: K Z.

description:
One of the best bakeries in town and lovely decorated cakes.
Love the buns and pastry selections...the swiss rolls (cake rolls with cream in center) are my favorite but so are their taro buns, red bean buns, etc etc....
author: Yan M.

description:
The worst service ever! They gave me the wrong change. I bought a couple of 
pastries.It cost something like $4.05. I gave the clerk $10.05. She gave me back $1.
When I remined her that I gave her $10.05, she refused to double-check. 
She insisted that I left the phone number and that the store would contact me when 
(or if) they "find extra five dollars" at the end of the business day. Rather than 
resolving the problem right away, they were rude and extremely unfriendly. 
I've never felt so insulted in my entire life. I will never go back again.
author: Ching S.

description: I really like the loafs of bread. They have raisin, custard, cream, etc. They are great for family snack items and is cheaper than buying a bunch of individual pastries, although their patries are delicious too.
author: Andy M.

description:
Sheng Kee is an ambassador between two worlds.  With its variations on classic Chinese buns, it tries to lure in Americanized Chinese customers while towing along their old school Chinese customers.

I fall into the former category and appreciate that there are English labels telling me exactly which buns I am picking out, but I also yearn for the flavors that are missing when comparing Sheng Kee buns to Chinatown bakery buns.  Sheng Kee seemingly takes a classic Chinese bun and sweetens it noticeably to bestow it a universal appeal.

Although Sheng Kee buns do not provide ultimate satisfaction, I still eagerly grab a few whenever the occasion arises.  My favorites include the hot dog green onion bun and red bean filled pineapple bun.
author: Andrew M.

description: The cakes and pastries are delicious... But the service here is awful. I went to buy my gma a cake for her birthday, while I was paying the lady gave me the wrong cake. I tried to tell her but she just threw my change at me and shouted next. Finally after ten mins they gave me the right cake. So frustrating.
author: Annabelle S.

description:
Bought the Mixed fruit sponge cake yesterday for a birthday party and never have I been so embarressed! 

THE CAKE WAS FROZEN! The fruits inside the cake was icy and the inside frosting was frozen! And trust me this isn't suppose to be a ice cream cake, I don't even think they sell ice cream cakes. Way to dissappoint Shen Kee! Even the little kids past on the cake! 

The sad part was I even asked the girl what was inside that cake and she had no clue, she said its can fruits and the cake was fresh and just came out! LIES i tell you, we even had the cake sit out for about an hour before we cut the cake due to not having enough room in the fridge, so imaging if we did refriderate that cake.. totally bummed! Sheng Kee Bakery has failed me so many times for cakes that i think i'll only come back for the buns and rolls!
author: Jacinta D.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Yummy yummy yummy! 

I really like their cream cheese buns and their cream cheese toast loaf. I guess I just like their cream cheese mixture. So fattening but oh so delicious. 

I also like their honey cake rolls except I honestly think they're lemon flavored. I also bought cakes from them like two years ago. Almost comparable to Schubert's but Schubert's wins. 

Their service is a little rude but nothing you can't just brush off. 

However, they are pretty expensive for an Asian bakery. About 1.20ish? per bun, it's ridiculous especially when you can get about the same for 0.60 in Chinatown. However, they are close and convenient and I'll definitely come back for more.
author: Bonnie L.

description: I have never been a fan of Chinese pastry, but was walking by one day and saw they had more variety and seemed to be expanding more into French pastries which I do prefer. I applaud the attempt, but it definitely still has a Chinese influence to it that made it way too bread-y and less like a pastry.
author: Carrie W.

description: Come in and grab a cheap snack. Hot Dog buns and blueberry/cream cheese danishes. Sure, they're terrible for you, but sometimes its exactly what you want.
author: Daniel C.

description: Various types of pastry here and wide hangout place. I had the milk tea and Portuguese egg tart, which I enjoy a lot. Recommended for people that want a place to hangout or relax.
author: Gooi Z.

description:
I've had multiple of the fruit type cakes from here, including a strawberry one for my birthday, and always enjoy them.  They always seem fresh, and I love how light-tasting they are, even though I'm sure I'm ingesting tons of calories.

The main reason I am docking stars is because all of the individually wrapped baked goods in the front are made with margarine.  The last time I went in I looked at all of the ingredient lists because I really wanted some sort of bun, but to my dismay, everything I saw listed margarine, no butter.  What bakery uses margarine??  It needs to be butter people!  Butter is better!  

Despite the fact that I can taste an obvious difference, I'm also of the belief that margarine is actually bad for you.  It's one molecule away from being plastic, it doesn't ever mold, and even flies won't touch it.  Try leaving some out if you don't believe me.  If that doesn't make you want to steer clear of the stuff, I don't know what will!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
3.5 stars.

Good pastries but they're pricey comparing to other bakeries in SF. 
Should try: Pineapple coconut, pineapple custard, egg custard.
author: Chew H.

description:
I love the baked goods here, although I can't help but feel like I am supporting a corporation whenever I purchase anything here... One of my favorite things is their green tea with red bean roll.  I love their variety of buns, but I can't help feeling as if there are better buns elsewhere.

I know of better bakeries elsewhere, that are more mom-and-pop places
author: Fannie S.

description: Love all of their mousse cakes! My current favorite is the french chestnut. The prices has sure gone up though. From what I remember about this place, they only accept cash (unless they changed it recently.. but the westlake location does take cards!) Good thing BoFA is next door. I'm not too crazy about their buns and other pastries. The po-tats are alright when very fresh, but gets kind of oily.
author: Allyson L.

description: I like this bakery because the have tasty cakes and light sandwiches. We usually get birthday cakes from here and they have not disappointed so far. They do have fresh selections of pastries that are good but nothing like the ones in LA's 85 degrees.
author: Jennie W.

description:
I actually went to Sheng Kee today to get a slice of roll cake, but when I walked in, I was amazed how many buns and breads they had. I couldn't decide what to get, I wanted to buy one of each kind. Finally, I decided to get the Taro Bun ($1.25). The bun was big and light. It had a sweet taro filling and slivered almonds on top. I couldn't wait to get home and eat it. God, it was good. Sticky, fluffy dough with sticky sweet paste inside. 
I also like how all buns are individually packaged in resealable mini plastic bags :] .
I will come back and try other buns.... and the roll cake! and also mini cakes. I love this bakery. Oh, can't wait to visit them again!
author: ponch l.

description:
I'm not much of a typical sweets person (i.e. not a fan of cookies and cakes and the like) but for some odd reason I really do like sweetened versions of traditionally savory things... such as bread, sweet potato fries and kettle corn.  Yes I am a weirdo.  Anyway...

BAKED GOODS:  Sheng Kee carries my all-time favorite sweet breads.  Love love love me some Toasted Coconut Bread, Red Bean Toast, Custard Bread and even their Raisin bread is good (I am not a huge fan of raisins as they remind me of mouse turds) .  Also have bomb-ass mouse cakes - I'm totally in love with their mango and chestnut mousse (I know it sounds nasty but just try it!!! it's amazingly refreshing).

AMBIENCE: Cute bakeshop right in the heart of SF's third Chinatown (this is an ongoing debate - I say the first Chinatown is the touristy one by Nob Hill that everyone knows about, the 2nd one is on Clement street in the Richmond District, the 3rd one is on Irving).  It is always warm and toasty and smells wonderfully like freshly baked  bread in here.   If I could bottle the smell of Sheng Kee bakery believe me I would.  One star knocked off just because service can range from being awkward to indifferent to just plain rude at times.  I've learned the secret is to say as little as possible - just grab what you want, bring it to the counter, pay and go.  Then pig out on what you just bought! MOOOO!!!!

PRICES: Are actually not bad at all.  Last I checked a whole loaf of one of their specialty breads is still $2.99.  And the cakes should still be around $30, maybe a little more for the mousse cake.

PARKING: Is a royal pain in the (___I___)  Try to walk there if you can.  Otherwise you have to deal with Asian Moms driving around in minivans they can't park... we know how that is...
author: Catherine C.

description:
Sheng Kee is one of my favourite bakeries and I've always only gone to the one in Milpitas so when I found this place after moving to San Francisco I was a very happy camper.  It's a much bigger store than the one in milpitas, has tables for you to sit and enjoy your baked goods, but the baked goods section is just a tiny corner of the store.  I think they might be more known for their cakes at this location since almost every time I've gone someone was either ordering or picking up a cake.  It def makes me want to try it out next time I have a reason to buy a cake! The pasteries are just as good as the one in Milpitas but the selection isn't as wide.  They have a lot more interesting choices but I like the simple pineapple buns and such. A lot of the time they don't have it (I'm just assuming I come to late and they run out) which makes me a little upset since it's what made me fall in love with Sheng Kee. 

All in all, with such a big location I think they should take away a few tables and use that space to put our more baked goods for us!
author: Alice L.

description: Shen Kee has been one of my goto places for birthday cakes for years, until yesterday. I picked out a very pretty Fruit Basket Cake on display in the frig. However, as the store clerk brought it out of the display, she carelessly smeared the giant strawberry that was sitting on top of the cake against the roof of the display and knocked it on the shelf. What really got me was that she proceeded to use a plastic glove to pick up the strawberry from the murky shelf and placed it back on my cake!!?! Needless to say, I told her that I didn't want that cake because it was unsanitary. She rudely responded declaring nothing was wrong with the cake. Fortunately, before a cake fight pursued, another more mature clerk stepped in to assist me with selecting another cake. I selected another cake alright. But be warned, the clerk returned the unsanitary cake back in the frig to be sold to an unsuspecting customer. My feedback to Shen Kee management: make customer service training mandatory and have stricter food handling guidelines. I will not be returning.
author: Katie L.

description:
Last week I dropped by and discovered it to be close by San Francisco Department of Public Health.
Checking their health score indicates there is something wrong:
http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:2:8548371799552003::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:3241
author: Darwin B.

description:
Avoid their cakes. They're beautifully decorated, but they don't use "real" cake. The cake layers inside are exactly like what you'd find in a swiss roll. (And the closest they get to chocolate cake is 'chocolate flavored' well-at-least-it's-the-right-color swiss roll layers). The "whipped cream frosting" tastes extremely plastic and processed, not at all the way real whipped cream should taste.

Take all that money you use on expensive packaging and put it into your cakes! We'll notice.

For cakes, go to Schubert's or Blissful Bites!

4 stars for their coconut bread and curry beef horns.
author: Wendy M.

description: Remarkably solid Chinese-style bakery.  I didn't have any of the cakes or anything, just a few of the pastries, but they the flavors and textures all reminded me of my youth in exotic Southern California.  I don't know what that says about Chinese pastries in general, but I appreciate the taste of nostalgia regardless.
author: Norman S.

description:
Got the BBQ pork bun and the pineapple bun with custard.  
Both buns were fine, nothing to rave about, and room temperature.  The BBQ pork bun was average, and while the pineapple bun looked nicer than average with almond slices decorating the top, the flavor was dull.  More style than substance.  

As far as the set up, you pick what you want out of glass shelves and take it up to register to pay.  The inside was big and cleaner than most smaller mom and pop places, but the prices were higher as well.  Around $1 for what normally costs 70 cents.  Not breaking the bank, but there are better places for price and taste.  Do yourself a favor and go up the street to Sunset Bakery, or Chinatown if you can go that far.
author: Sam H.

description:
I LOVE THEIR CAKES. Light, fluffy, with fruit all over. If you haven't tried one before, you need to try one now because they are amazing. Nothing is too sweet or too bitter, and I usually get whatever is in the display because everything's good no matter what!

Their taro breads and dried shredded pork thing bread is so good. (Those breads with the swirled stuff in the center) yummyy
author: Colleen M.

description:
Not an 85C and definitely cannot be my substitute.  I've had better buns at smaller asian bakeries.  Their buns are nasty...I can taste the margarine they use in the bread.  The buns are super dense and greasy and not worth their price.  The mooncakes are good.  I like their lotus ones.  Their cakes are decent since they are the light sponge fruit cakes that all Chinese bakeries are known for, but nothing to write home about since they are more pricey here.  

What I used to love here were the loafs of taro bread.  Don't see them any more. :(  I will save my calories for 85C.
author: Cheryl L.

description: I know! cause My mom work at the bakery! & made all your birthday cakes or weddin' and the rest of the cakes! that she been working there for 27 years.
author: Julia D.

description:
I love perfect little Chinese buns!

(get your mind out of the gutter...I'm talking about the pastries)

Hot dog bun---savory and delicious with a little cheese in the pastry.
Taro bun---mild taro flavor, slightly sweet pastry...great for breakfast. 
Coconut bun---mild coconut flavor, sweet pastry...great with tea.
All are individually packaged to insure freshness as well as cuteness!

I am told that the prices here are high for a "Chinese" bakery, whatever that means.  I also thought this was a Taiwanese bakery?  Don't worry, I'm not going to go there...I'm too afraid to ask for clarification.  I may be white and American, but I've spent some time in Taipei and know better than to discuss Cross-Straight relations and China with the Taiwanese.   

I know this much, for sure...I will be back for more!
author: s r.

description: Red bean buns. My family loves them, especially the ones from Sheng Kee Bakery.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Sheng Kee Bakery is such a gem!

I work across the street from this bakery and am so glad that they are there for my pastry needs.

They have so many fresh baked rolls to choose from. Here are some of my favorites: green onion and cheese roll, chicken roll and the sweet bread roll. I don't know the correct names but I do know they are delicious and at $1.05-$2.00 (depending on the roll of course), it's a such a steal! They are big enough to fill you up and keep you satisfied.
author: Denise S.

description: I am not a big fan of overly sweet American desserts so Sheng Kee cakes are perfect for me. Asian cakes tend to be less heavy on the creme with more emphasis on fruit; Americans may find them a bit bland but they're perfect for me. Got a strawberry mousse cake that was delicious. The cake could have been a little more moist but I love the subtly sweet mousse.
author: Donna W.

description: :( omygod i'm so disappointed with their egg tarts! It was horrible! I usually am not picky abt egg tarts because of the fact that i LOVE em to death, but wow.. Shengkee broke my heart! They were very dry and tasteless! And the portuguese egg tarts? I thought it was gonna taste better but man was I wrong! It was 4x worseee! It was sticking to the aluminum plate thing. I couldn't even take the egg tart out. Very hard and messy to eat! The Portuguese egg tart was too soft that it was falling apart and still no taste. I'm so heart broken right now!
author: Verdina P.

description:
Taro, Custard and Red Bean...not your typical flavors. 

You can't find it in Grain D'Or, Boudin...not even in Krispy Kreme Donuts.

I speak to the fortunate few who live in San Francisco to be grateful that we are exposed to the richness that diverse peoples in this city have to offer in food

Sheng Kee Bakery is one of the best bakeries for you to try Chinese pastries such as the taro, custard and red bean bun. Each is wrapped in its own delightful little bag. If you stop by at around 10 am or whenever they open...they are displayed, fresh & warm, from the oven. The brown color is cooked perfectly & I think they put the right amount of bean paste in each bun (even though some prefer more in quantity but I think it would make the bun taste too sweet)

More than worth the price, it's different from your typically overpriced croissant 

May this be why the majority in China did not welcome Sarkozy at the Beijing Olympics?

Perhaps...chomp
author: Charmian D.

description: This bakery is the bomb!! We love it!! Delish and orginal baked goods! :)
author: Jd W.

description:
The funniest thing happen today; I was driving down Irving thinking about the Chinese pastries I used to have as a kid out on Taraval Street.  My mouth started watering and as I parked the car to go to the bank I looked up & in front of me was Sheng Kee.  I've never noticed it before, I suppose my subconscious was willing me towards it.  Anyhow when I noticed they have Chinese pastries I had to go in and did I ever.  i walked out of there with 5 sweet buns and egg bread!

OMG the coconut cream bun is superb.  I also got the pineapple bun, and a few others, but I can't remember what they were, but they were delish!  I am so glad I stumbled upon this place and I will definitely be going back as soon as I devour my pastry stash.

Also, the place was very clean & inviting.  I also, liked how all the pastries were individually wrapped.  

FYI its cash only.
author: Molly M.

description: Overpriced, individually-wrapped meh (yes, I'm using "meh" as a noun here).  They justify the higher prices because it looks clean inside and everything is packaged somewhat better than most other Chinese bakeries, but when it comes down to flavor, there's really nothing that special that I wouldn't be able to find better tasting and cheaper somewhere else.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I feel like this location's quality may have went down. I had a mango mousse cake from this location, barely tasted like mango or even sweet at all. I also ordered my favorite green tea and red bean roll. There was something not quite right about it. The flavor was kinda sharp and made my tongue itch a little. I was very disappointed since I have been coming here for years and it is closer to my house then another Sheng Kee.  

Sheng Kee may be a chain which means same quality at all locations, but I rather go to the Sheng Kee at Westlake.
author: Jess H.

description: I found a baked fly in my bacon bun today.  I have posted the pictures.  No more buy one get one free after 7pm for the fatty.  BTW I still ate the bun.  I probably have swine flu now.  Sucks to be a fatty.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Love their pastries and cakes!

We come here to get some of their cakes for birthdays and they're great! Colorful, sweet, and decently sized for an ok price. They look like fancy cakes with chocolate pieces and decorations. 

I'd like to come here when everything is fresh, but to me, it's pretty expensive. After 5 or so is when I'd come in. Cheaper prices and still yummy pastries.

I haven't tried too many foods here but I'm sure they're all great in their own way. If you want to get a pretty cake for your friend or loved one, come to Sheng Kee! Cakes with mango mousse and chocolate, mmmm... so good.
author: robin w.

description: If it says 'taro' or 'mochi' (bonus: or both!) on the description, rest assured you'll be happy.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
This is an excellent cake place BUT I'm going to talk about buns!

They have a great selection of breakfast buns (made fresh every morning) that come in little resealable plastic wrapping. Recently, I got the Corn and Ham Bun, the Tuna Bun, and the Hot Dog Onion Bun for $3.75. The Corn and Ham sits on a a small dab of mayo that rests on top of a pretty awesome, sweet-bread-type bun. The same goes for the Tuna and Hot Dog Onion buns. The Tuna bun comes with a little drizzle of tomato sauce which makes it equally good as a lunch bun. And the Hot Dog Onion Bun is pretty straight forward. 

I also recommend the red bean bread (which has red bean paste swirled around in the dough before it's baked) -- but do make sure to eat it within three days because after three days, bread dries up and it's really hard to recapitulate the sweet wonderful-ness that is red bean bread in the toaster oven.

They also have a refrigerated section with actual lunch sandwiches ($1.49-1.75): Chicken Salad, Tuna and Egg, Ham+Tomato+Lettuce, just to name a few. If you're in that section and end up eye-ing the individual slides of roll cake ($0.85), turn around, walk towards the cake display and get the full roll ($4.99) instead. 

I come here pretty often, and I always leave happy.
author: Julia L.

description: I loved the red bean moon cake pastry. But there was a mocha cream cone which was entirely too sweet and rich, hence the 3 stars. I'd return for the red bean moon cake fo sho. Plus there is no minimum on credit card charges! Sweet!
author: Monica A.

description: Love it. The Portuguese egg tarts were amazing.
author: Terry B.

description:
the only time their baked buns are nice and hot is in the morning when they freshly bake it, which is very early in the morning, so  i do not recommend coming here in the afternoon if you're looking for hot pastries.

this place is ONLY good for cold pastries and cakes.

did i mention that their items are overpriced? $1.75 for an egg tart? no thanks!
author: M R.

description:
Awesome cakes!!!  I tried green tea and mango.
Green tea was okay but mango cake was really good!
And the price! It was cheap [$1.85 a piece]
I tried cake at Cafe Madeleine which cost me $5.50/piece.
Sheng Kee is far better or both taste and price : )
author: Jay A.

description:
have you tried their sliced white bread with swirls of custard in the middle?

bomb

the mango cake with alternating white and mango chocolate pieces surrounding...

pretty good.

this place, can't go wrong pastry wise but serious, try that sliced white bread with custard swirls..you will NOT regret
author: Whitne Y.

description:
I came here today to get a cake...and the selection of cakes here are great! They have everything from mousse cakes, cheese cakes, flavored cakes, and fruit cakes. All the cakes here are so pretty too. Almost too pretty to eat. 

I often visit more casual types of bakeries when getting a cake. Once in a while I stop by here to pick up a cake, because the quality is pretty good and the presentation of the cake is beautiful. The lady behind the counter was very helpful in helping me pick a cake. Everything looked really sweet, so i wanted to get one that wasn't too sweet. I ended up getting the fruit basket cake($23). The cake itself is not like a typical spongy Chinese cake. It's a little more dense and more firm but its still light and not too sweet -which was perfect. The middle has whipped cream and mixed fruits - but it was fruit cocktail - and we all know that's from a can. I prefer fresh fruits..but that's okay. I think it has a layer of custard or something on top of the cake, topped with whipped cream and tons of fresh kiwi's, strawberries and peach. 

Overall they have all the typical Asian style pasties here from your breads, pork buns, cocktail buns, cookies, etc. I heard that after 7pm everything is 1/2 off - hmm..I wonder if that applies to cakes? =P Overall, the cake is good, but I prefer the more Chinese style fluffy sponge cake.
author: Betty S.

description: Perfect for small-snack munchies (red bean cake, mini flan cup).
author: Inigo M.

description:
They got it all.  They got cakes, buns, sandwiches, various desserts, cookies, drinks, etc.

Even with the impressive selection of baked goods, I only come here for the strawberry mousse cake (I'm a creature of habit, don't hate!).

The cake is lightly made, slightly less dense than your average "Chinese cake".  It's not overpowering in the sweet department and the mousse is a wonderful alternative to white frosting.  The presentation is done beautifully and each time I buy it, everyone always approves.  WIN WIN!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Would be good if this store had a line for the cashiers/to pay for products. Maybe a ticket machine to call out customer numbers or just a set line/ropes for people to stand in.
I go there a lot -- and everytime some little old lady tries to cut in front of me! And pretends she was 'in line' before me. It's rude and makes me want to never spend any money at a store that is not organized. With a nice orderly line - -the store would sell a lot more pasteries/baked goods AND customers would be happy.

All the products there are very nice and tasty. Esp. the buns and tarts.

But they need to organize a better way to check out without getting into a screaming match or worse, a shoving match with someone else. It seems the more pushy, more elbows you throw -- you get to cut the line. I could step on these ladies like bugs -- but then that would be wrong.
author: John G.

description:
Holy crap, you sell "Vietnamese" sandwiches. And I quote Vietnamese because it has everything a Vietnamese sandwich would have in it (carrots, cucumber, cilantro, radish, meat, etc), only that their cucumber and carrots are cut much larger than the shreds I'm used to. Also, the fancy pork isn't quite fancy pork because it had little peppercorns in it. There is also a slice of ham in the mix, different, but nice addition. And the sign says "sub-sandwiches" but you know what I mean.

Funny thing is that they have these ready-made sitting by the registers on the counter above. Just grab n go for lunch!...that is of course after you pay $2.99 for the sandwich. Despite not being made in front of me, it still tasted fresh and I'm pretty sure they bake their own bread considering this is a Chinese bakery. 

I guess I should also take this time to say that I also love their mousse cakes and fruit tarts. I could eat this whole bakery if I had a longer lunch break.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Really good buns! Love the cheese and ham bun. Their sandwiches are 50 percent off after 6 o'clock but they still taste fresh at the time. I'm not a big fan of their cakes though.
author: Allie Y.

description: Sheng Kee has the best cakes and buns from cosmopolitan China. I highly recommend the bakery. The interior is presentable compared to other local bakeries. Most of the products are sweet and not salty. The cakes are flawlessly designed and the buns are offered in a wide variety. My favorite is the custard bun and something with chocolate inside. The cashiers are not that easy to deal with, but are always ready for you to pay. The products are inexpensive.
author: Denise C.

description:
This bakery sets the standard for excellence.

It's not cheap, but you get what you pay for. I'm talking about their cakes.
author: Miguel T.

description: Grew up with their buns and they have always been very good! Recently, they have been coming out with new buns.  The hawaiian bun is very good!
author: Carol K.

description:
Please open up a Sheng Kee in Marin... PLEASE PLEASE!
I miss walking down the street at 7pm and getting half priced deals on Pork buns, Taro buns and Custard buns, well on ALL buns.  I always come out with a smile every time I leave Sheng Kee.  I still need to try one of their cakes, they look so beautiful and hopefully are tasty as well.
author: Crystal R.

description:
Ive been coming to Sheng Kee bakery since before I could walk and it has been apart of me since then. There are so many other varieties of bread, wheat, multi grain, 7-grain, wonderbread, sourdough, etc etc...but Sheng Kee's Taiwanese full loaf still rates number 1 on my list of breads. 
It is always delicious, with just enough sweetness and firm texture that keep me coming back....no not like crack, cuz drugs are BAD!

Their take on the vietnamese sandwich isnt too bad either and their sweet pastries and coffee cakes are always spot on! 

OO DISCLAIMER: 
as a child, i began to slowly hate regular cakes and all those cakes my friends (who were mainly white) would eat/have on their birthdays. I remember times where i would simply refuse cake and have mothers force feeed it to me. This was all because of Sheng Kee....their cakes are naturally less sweet, not overloaded with sugar and frosting, and were the only cakes i would eat as a child. To this day, i still despise normal frosting and always take the other option at birthday parties....altho even those are becoming rarer and rarer.
author: Jason W.

description:
Went into this large bakery on the busier side of Irving where all the Asian stores are. Always looking for good Asian food- including breads, but was very disappointed. I had two buns - one a puff pastry bun with shredded pork, and the other a coconut bun. Both were not very good and I had to nearly force myself to finish it since I didn't have a good lunch.
They have friendly counter people, but the buns are not very good here.
author: Bryan S.

description: Carb lady here! What can I say, I love my buns! I always get a little tooooo excited and leave with more then I should (esp. the savory ones, yummm). As for the cakes, try the mango mousse cake! It was so tasty, I bought an entire cake despite there being any special occasion!
author: Karen H.

description:
Pretty darned good.  I had a bun with corn and mayo filling, and a hot dog bun with green onions, as well as a mocha roll for dessert.  Not the best hot dog bun I have had, but they were warm and didnt look like it had been sitting out all day long. And the mayo on my corn bun didnt give me a stomachache from being god knows where for god knows how long. 
Definately yummy, and makes me want to go back to try the sweeter pastries and buns.
author: Janet R.

description: I'm generally very careful about diet selection, but this bakery is one of my few exceptions for unhealthy choice of foods. My favorite is the pineapple custard raisin toast. It tastes like heaven when you warm it up at home in a toaster. The fact that it's 160 calories and 6g of fat per slide does not stop me from driving all the way there just to get the toast. The price is definitely not cheap ($3.99). In fact it's even higher than some of those healthy toast at Wholefoods.  The pineapple custard bun and the almond custard bun taste pretty much the same. The loaded sweet fillings left me feeling really guilty for ever consuming them. I have no excuse but telling myself it's a treat once in a while. Cash only.
author: Elle W.

description:
i wouldn't buy pork buns from Sheng Kee because its disgusting 

please go to cafe bakery if you are craving for a pork bun (the best!)
http://www.yelp.com/biz/B0lqvrhX9BNPMggTFmFj8g

HOWEVER, Sheng Kee does offer wide variety of breads that are good. they are known for their unique flavors bread loafs -- ie. red bean loaf, custard raisin loaf, PLAIN loaf, raisin loaf. everything is good and DIRT CHEAP! you can buy a $2.50 whole loaf of bread for dinner! 

Also, Sheng Kee offers HALF PRICE on ALL sandwiches (in the cold section) after 6pm (not 3 or 5 minutes before 6pm, but EXACTLY after 6pm.

*2 minutes before 6pm*

me: (carrying two Vietnamese sandwiches to the cashier) 
cashier: (rang up $5.98) sorry you have to wait 2 more minutes
me: really?!! its ONE minute before 6pm
cashier: yea, the computer doesn't read the half price yet
friend: *laughing* THIS IS CRAZYYY. i cant believe it makes a difference
me: (waiting and looking at the clock as it finally turn 6pm)
cashier: OK! $3.00 please

TIP: you have to buy them starting at 6pm because their computer/cashier doesn't read the half price until its 6pm. weird isn't it?!!  PLEASE just let me have my Vietnamese sandwich for $1.50 please!!! (the sandwich isn't worth $2.99  BUT its definitely worth $1.50)
author: Carol Y.

description:
I don't usually think of the Chinese as being masters of bread, but hey, SF is about defying stereotypes, right?

Apparently Sheng Kee has quite the operation going, with 10 Bay Area locations (of which this is the only one in SF) dating back 50 years to a little place in Taipei.  Based on what I saw here, I'm guessing it's the buns that made them famous.

They have lots of flavors both sweet and savory, some stuffed, some with toppings.  I tried the Pork Sung, good but a little odd--what's that carpety stuff on top? [Judy K: it's the pork sung, aka rousong, aka meat floss.  Nummy!].  Also had a Pineapple Taro bun, which was pure bliss.  There's plenty of tables but no atmosphere, so I recommend grabbing your stuff to go, picking up a boba at Wonderful Foods, and heading into GGP for a delicious walk and/or picnic.

Also a good spot to get moon cakes.
author: Wes M.

description:
Can't go a few days without slammin some incredibly sweet and exquisitely made coconut-creme-raisin toast that i have to keep replenished throughout the week as the perfect compliment to my morning kohi.

Its like 2.50 for a loaf which is crazy cheap for how much work it seems they put into concocting this morsel of oral pleasure.  I have the most fun just watching many of the cute, hk girls working get all excited and stressed out when they are busy during the day.

You hear them all yelling, screaming, laughing, and stickling their tongues out at each other...it makes me wanna throw on an apron and join them in the madness.  Ya gotta try the curry puff---oishii yo!
author: omar b.

description: Cute little bakery in San Francisco, near San Tung's. We ordered to go and decided to stroll the streets while we waited. The goods here are yummy and range from savory to sweet, and don't cost much either! A nice little place to stop by and buy some snacks for the next day. We came at the end of the day so they were out of  lot of things already.
author: Jacqueline N.

description: I live a block away from Sheng Kee, and I absolutely hate it because its impossible for me just to walk by. Everything is so delicious. My favorite is the chocolate bun. Its huge, and is only 1.85. This place is the gem of the Outer Sunset.
author: Magdalena G.

description:
i have a confession:
i adore Sheng Kee's buns.
there's just no resisting
the sweet coconut ones.

they're so cute and pudgy 
with deep golden sheen,
yellow coconut paste
and tan sesame seeds.

i could have selected
any other delight,
but nothing compares--
it was love at first bite.
author: M A N I K.

description: I love their mango cakes here and their half ham/turkey cheese sandwiches. They always have fresh Chinese pastries! Mmm. I miss this.
author: Vivian L.

description: I've walked past Sheng Kee Bakery twice and have stopped in for a pastry both times.  On first try, the redbean pastry was delightful.  On second try the custard pastry topped with roasted almond slices was amazing!  I know what I'm getting the third time :)
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Sheng Kee's method for keeping prices low seems to be to reduce the amount of filling in the buns.  It seems like every year, there's less filling.  When you bite into a red bean bun, it's mostly air, which is frustrating.   I mean there's only a teaspoon of red bean paste in there and the rest is AIR.  The bun is the same size on the outside but the shell is thin, hence it's an air pocket.  I'd rather pay more to have more filling in the bun.

But complaints aside, their buns are tasty and they make really good cakes (the rolls with a thin layer of cream, the triangle wedges).  I've had their large cakes too and they're just right.  Western cakes tend to be too sweet but the Asian bakeries, like Sheng Kee, tone down the sweetness of their cakes.

They have good bread too, especially the red bean bread.  The Taiwan toast is really good after it's been toasted.  I also come here every year for mooncakes. The mini ones are good and just the right size and you can choose the kinds you like which is better than buying a prepackaged box of mooncakes.
author: Lolia S.

description:
