Sheng Kee!  Why does everyone in my family love you???  I cannot count the number of bday cakes I have consumed from your bakery!

Do I like you?  YES!

Do I love you?  No.

My family loves the fresh fruit in your cake...especially the fruit medley one!  Me?  It tastes like fruit-cocktail on sponge cake.

They find you simply delish!  I wonder what that odd cream is you use in your cake...almost the consistency of blended cottage cheese?

They say they love how you are not too sweet.  I think a cake should be sweeeeeeeeeet.  Your cake consistency is a bit thicker, similar to a Jelly Roll...great for a jelly roll, but not what I look for in a cake.

Oh, Sheng Kee...they went to you for my birthday cake last week.  I sat and pondered why?  Why, when they know I love sweet, fresh, light cream filling in my cake...and prefer the cake consistency to be a light, spongy texture that is slightly moist not jelly-rollish... why?  Because they LOVE you...and it doesn't matter what I think.  

I left your jelly-roll like strawberry cake with the odd cream at my mom's and did not take a slice home.  How you thrill their taste buds.  I on the other hand, will head over to Clement for a late bday cake from me to me.

Sheng Kee...you are alright.  Great to some...but just okay, to me.

3.5 stars...not quite 4.
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
I like their stuff here but often times what they ring up and the prices on the shelves are totally different and when I tell them that it's like they are stupid, deaf or something. They just keep on repeating the price that doesn't match the prices on the shelf so I end up paying more than it was on the shelf so I stopped coming. That Chinese girl is stupid. I told her the drink is $1 and she quoted me another price like $1.20 or something. And when I told her that, she just looked at me and keep repeating the same price $1.20 as if she's stupid and a robot don't understand what I'm talking about.

I used to come here every day. But I stopped, since that incident. That was the second or third time. I don't like giving people second chances anymore.
author: Robin T236532i9 W.

description: I have been to this Sheng Kee Bakery at 1941 Irving Street several times before... This Sheng Kee Bakery is a little bit bigger than the one that they have at the 99 Ranch Shopping Area but they have the some kind of the yummy deserts and baked goods that, I like to eat... My favorite yummy things that... I like to buy and eat from this Sheng Kee Bakery at the Irving Street area is the Ham & Cheese bun, Green Tea Mini Size Moon Cake & The Fruit Cake whiich is one of my favorite cake and not to sweet and yummmmmy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: William B.

description:
Ive known Mark and Joy the owners of Sheng Kee since i was still a wee little boy. Back then, they only really had this one bakery and then got a factory and etc etc. 

I used to work in the stock room at their factory, fold boxes during mooncake season, make the rolling trays, package mooncakes and bag up toast. etc etc etc....

Anyways, its just nice to see a place you've grown up with still around. 

I still enjoy their chicken pie things not sure why..and their napoleans are still yum..I dont really eat much cakes but if someone  does happen to have one for a birthday or celebration its always been quite yum~
author: phillip w.

description: Great selection of pastries. Every time I go here the place is clean and have a great variety of food. The place is a little pricey, but you most likely will find unique and different pastries here.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
Come here at 6:45pm on weekdays to gather all the choice buns near the window shelves.  Every weekday after 7:00pm, it's 2 for $1.25.  But come here right before, at around 6:55, then you're in for a shoving match plus all the hot dog buns are usually gone.  

I guess this bakery is a routine stop for all the Chinese ladies in the neighborhood because they must loiter around outside waiting until it nears 7pm.  At times I couldn't get a hand in to get a bacon bun.

Just beat them Chinese ladies out of the way cuz you can have breakfast for an entire week for about $5.
author: Chris T.

description:
one doesn't have to go here for sheng kee bakeries. they are all over the bay area, either standalone or in conjuction with ranch 99 or lions et al. 

i've been blessed to have tasted some of their mooncakes, birthday cakes, and toasted almond/cashew cookies. just GREEAT!
author: Victor G.

description:
this is a review only about their cakes as I have not tried their pastries.

very asian cakes that are not too sweet, with a soft fluffy center, and variations of mousse flavors and toppings that include fruits and flavored chocolates. I would describe the cakes as a fusion of traditional chinese cake with a western world twist . Overall a very satisfying cake and at $24 for a cake that serves 10+, not to bad. they have several locations located in daly city and in the sunset for customer convenience.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Ok, I was wrong. This is Taiwanese bakery indeed. I thought it's cantonese because none of the bakeries in Taiwan nowadays serve items like they do in Sheng Kee. Don't get me wrong, they taste very good, but if it were in Taiwan, it would be terribly out of date. It's sooooo old-fashioned, but once in fashion for sure. I ate breads like Sheng kee's when I very very young, so that's like 20 years ago. In Taiwan, no one would buy things like those anymore, but here, it's a great place to go for nostalgic purpose.

Wow. 
Although I prefer the bakeries in Taiwan so much more than this cantonese bakery, still, it's the best I've tried in US, better than the Tapan bakery in NYC.

You might wonder why you don't get any pineapple in the pineapple buns. It refers to the checkered shape of its top, not the taste of pineapple. At home, it's the cheapest bread in any bakery that you only get it when everything else is out. But here, they remind me of home so I fall in love with them after visiting sheng kee.

My favorite is the Pineaple Taro loaf. A whole loaf of yummy bread costs $3.75? Must be kidding! So cheap and it'll last for a week!

The moon cakes are very good and it comes in 10 flavors or so. The jasmine and oolong are my favorite. 

Ok, here comes the Taro mochi cake. I grew up in the town where taro mochi cake originated. It is THE dessert at the president's table when he holds dinner parties for foreign VIP. It's called the national treat in taiwan. I would never imagine to find them in a cantonese bakery. But they are indeed, pretty good here.
author: Yuchi C.

description: The place I go to when I a) forget I'm trying to be calorically good or b) want to wander around on Irving Street for goodies to put in my messenger bag. The hot dog in a cheese bun makes me forget that I don't like hot dogs, the almond cookies are pure elysium, the custard buns are ambrosial sugar madness, the white sweet bread is god with peanut butter and strawberry jelly, I heart the fruit tarts so much it hurts (aching surging overwhelming love pains pumping through the ventricles), the vietnamese sandwiches are fab, and the mocha creme buns are my ultimate undoing. Basically, you can't really go wrong with anything at Sheng Kee.
author: Natasha P.

description: Recently also tried the mango mousse cake which was pretty good (still not the biggest fan of mousse), but it was beautifully decorated. Today I got the green tea w/ red bean cake because I couldn't decide and the colors and decoration was just so perfect. I am a fan of green tea, but not a fan of red beans. And that was exactly how my liking turned out to be when I had the cake. Props for being open till 8pm even on a Sunday though. Pretty good service. But CASH ONLY, which somewhat sucks. Parking will always be a BITCH around this area.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Sheng Kee is the place for carb overload.  They have a big variety of fun, tasty, rolls, pastries, buns and cakes to choose from.  Some of my faves are the taro buns, pork sung buns and red bean buns - can you tell?  I like buns -- hurhurhur.  They also have a pretty good warm bbq puff pastry and warm curry beef pastry.

The Irving store has a better variety than the Westlake location but everything they have is yummo.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
moon cakes, i missed you! geez, i haven't had a mooncake in years and this was a special treat for me to find this.
taro pastries - i didn't know you existed and i'm happy i found you!
chicken pot pies - my perfect little snack on the go!

i was very pleasantly surprised to find this place after hitting Golden Gate Park. such a great chinese bakery with everything individually wrapped. great to buy a bunch of things for breakfast, parties, or asap
author: Chanda I.

description:
The last time I went to Sheng Kee I ordered the Coconut Taiwan Toast Bread. Although economical, Margarine is not what I would consider to be a food. Out of fashion since the nineties, there are many good health reasons to avoid the stuff, but my primary complaint is that to anyone with a decent palate, the stuff is gross!
It was a horrible disappointment to bite into coconut mixed with Margarine swirled in this bread. I would have prefered honey, butter, coconut oil, even lard would be less disgusting. What a horrible thing to do to such a beautiful bread!

I am a fan of nearly everything this bakery does, but wish that they would change the bread recipe to more reflect modern taste and health conciousness. Why is the coconut bread only available in white bread? Why would I willingly consume margarine in 2009?

I will be buying the margarine free foods that this fine establishment offers. It is really a lovely bakery. MARGARINE IS GROSS!
author: Kimberley M.

description: Great boba. Great desserts. I accidentally ordered the wrong thing and they switched it out for free!! Thanks again!
author: Vera F.

description:
I'm a PIROSKI junkie! Sadly, I've not been able to find any bakery on the East Bay that sells the delectables, and have to travel all of 45 minutes to Irving Street to get my fix. I grew up in HK, and lived above a bakery that sold  three kinds (are there more?). Sheng Kee brings back those good memories!

If anyone in the East Bay knows of a bakery that makes n bakes em, please let me know ...
author: June L.

description:
What's not to like? Fruit-topped cakes, all manner of Chinese buns and loaves. It's tasty stuff.

Parking can be really horrible in the immediate area ... but you probably knew that.
author: Jason K.

description: I know this place is popular for their pastry products. For me, their cakes are too sweet and rich for my tastes, though. That's just my opinion, because I was asked to buy a cake from them once for a New Year's Eve party.
author: H K.

description:
Sheng Kee, I heart you so much.  On days when I'm craving dan tats (egg tarts) from Golden Bakery in Chinatown, I can't fathom the thought of driving through the crowded streets and then to find parking for that one dan tat.  That's when you come to my rescue. If I'm lucky enough to buy you at 7:00pm, I can get another one of you for free. Two dan tats for $1.50.  And to spice it up even more, you come in two types of dan tats.  Your basic dan tat or Portuguese dan tat, which has become my ultra fave.

I love you.
author: hello k.

description:
I have a problem with baked goods, and when I say problem I mean I can't stay away from them!

Most of the time I crave rich pastries, but sometimes I want something lighter. When this happens Asian baked goods come to my rescue! At Sheng Kee their goodies are light and not too sweet. They are the best Asian bakery I have found (in terms of variety and quality) and is luckily right down the street! 

They also make the most beautiful cakes! These cakes seriously look like pieces of art. Luckily you have the option of buying just a slice so you can see if they cakes taste as good as they look without spending serious cash (and by serious cash I mean around 25 dollars).

My only complaints are with their savory items, I've tried a few and wasn't impressed, but I hear their ham and cheese rolls are pretty good. The staff is pretty unhelpful so if you have any questions it might be better to ask other shoppers.
author: rachel c.

description: All the buns are super fresh and all are packed individually.
author: Katie K.

description:
Yum.

Count on the Chinese to make things cheap (without lead, I hope).

Why aren't there more bakeries like this one?  The red bean bread was fantastic.  I'm going back for one of their cakes, which are surprisingly affordable for how much attention to detail was put into them.  Check back for an updated rating...
author: Chris R.

description: Honestly, this is a great place to get cake. I always come here for the cakes and the bread. They also have a lot of different locations which is awesome
author: aryana c.

description:
Most times, I prefer a French bakery to Chinese bakery. But, the taro bread at Sheng Kee is something French people know nothing about. I love how gooey the taro is, and the bread is super soft (I know, it's white bread so it's not that healthy... so what). 

As for the other baked goods, I'm not too much a fan of their cakes- but mostly because I just don't like that style of cake.
author: anocha s.

description: I am so frustrated with the website. I am looking for a big cake and i am not able to find anything from the website. I am going somewhere else. It's a shame!@
author: Charles C.

description:
For: A Pork Bun by Any Other Name

The bbq baked pork buns here are not my favorite but they're ok.  They're somewhat on the dry side, and rather under-spiced.  The texture of the bun is a little elastic, while the filling almost completely lacks texture.  In fact, it looks to me like they pureed the filling before injecting it into the bun.  I would eat it again if I was hungry nothing else was on the shelves.

Pork buns aside, their green onion hot dog buns are one of my guilty pleasures, and their myriad of perfectly right-angled, ultra-modular bread loaves appeal to my inner robot.
author: Thomas M.

description:
I'm on a quest to find the best portuguese egg tart (on par with what I've had in Macau) in San Francisco.  The ones at Sheng Kee don't come close, unfortunately.

The curry beef horn is okay.  After a few bites, you realize something is missing....BUTTER!  I suspect they use shortening in the savory pastries here.  The mini-chicken pot pie is awful.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
All our beloved Chinese grannies hang out here, so it's got to be good, right??  Well, actually, mine prefer the cheaper places (and smartly so, I'd say), but Sheng Kee is not bad at all.

They have pretty good breads and pastries, but nowadays I only come here for two things: the curry beef pies(somewhat similar to a small empanada) for $.99 a piece and a box of flaky, buttery pastries called 'Tai Yeung Beng'  (Sunshine Cookies?!) - 8 for $6.99.
author: Kalista W.

description: love love love this place.. my friend took me here for the first time and i was in awe.. yummy goodies galore! all the breads, sweet and savory bun pastries, tarts, cakes, and so much more.. it's hard for me to decide what i want to place on my tray, i have my faves and want to try something new every time.. one year, my friend cooked me a bday dinner and got me 4 diff cake slices  from here as my dessert platter.. yumm
author: Raquel T.

description: Good pastries. Terrible coffee.
author: Wesh W.

description:
Had to get some moon cakes for the autumn festival weekend.
Shared it with the star of White On Rice.
The coconut was top with pineapple coming in a close second, and the chestnut moon cake was good regardless of coming third.

There other baked goods are what else, good.  Pineapple bun... mmmm.
author: Po L.

description:
I love the green tea cakes that are rolled up and served in slices. They have beans and cream and taste kinda like a twinkie. My fantasy is to buy the whole log and eat it all, the cake is so freekin' good.

The only draw-back is that they close kinda early, so when we go to P.P.Q. the bakery is closed when we come out. Gotta remember to buy our cakes before dinner.
author: kenneth m.

description:
Nothing fancy here folks. Just your average bakery. Sheng Kee has evolved into a huge corporation and with that being said, bigger factory sized bakeries. No longer are the cakes baked on premises, they're prepared somewhere, frozen and delivered. 

Numerous times have I had a cake from Sheng Kee that was still half thawed. 

I do however, favor their Chicken pies. Tiny little hand held pastries, with a flaky puff pastry crust. Their filling needs a little work. I can only imagine if they put the filling from Cafe Bakery on Noriega into their crust here. Mmmmmmm....
author: Derrick L.

description:
went there yesterday and saw what looked like a nice shiny, crusty apple pie,  picked it up and it was heavy! thought, maybe cuz there's lots of apples  but when i cut it open i found a solid, hard chewy doughy crust about 1/8" thick!!!!!  both top and bottom crust was like this and the rim was rolled over to form a round hard mass.!!  there was one thin layer of apple in between the crust.  the weight of this pie came from the DOUGH!!!
this was THE absolute WORST apple pie I have ever had.   for $5.99 it was a waste.
dont EVER buy this pie.
author: dee c.

description: Best egg Crust portuguese style and BBQ Pork pastry! Yum, Milk tea only $0.99
author: Jacqueline X.

description: I desperately needed a cake to surprise my dad on his birthday. It was almost 7PM and I was stuck in traffic on the Bay Bridge, freaking out! Thankfully, my bff called and asked them when they'd close. 7:30, phew, I still had about half an hour. Anyway, when I got there, it was about 7:15, and there were still plenty of people waiting inside. They were really quick and I got in and out in about five minutes.  The lady who helped me was pretty nice too and did everything with a smile, which I really appreciated. The cakes are reasonably priced, and are pretty good (try the mango mousse one). And they pretty much write anything you want on your cake. Once we asked them to write "Happy Birthday Bitch!!" and they did. Hahaha, good times. And I'm sure their other baos and other such items are good too.
author: Audrey T.

description: My family always always get the baked buns here. They're very addicting! My girls can finish a whole bag (each bag has 12 buns) in a day and a half. I also like their raisin loaf. They're baked fresh everyday. I usually come here for the bread loaf but their cakes look/sound good too!
author: Jean T.

description: By FAR one of my FAVORITE Asian bakeries. I love getting the little angel food cakes and other special little items they sell here. They also have a location in Daly City which I tend to go to more since we take our fur baby grooming in the area and it's less of a hassle to get to. But whenever we're eating at Pho Hoa Hiep on Irving or going to Wonderful foods we stop by and take some pastries to go.
author: Petra S.

description:
LOVE the pastries here! Not healthy at all, but what pastry is. 

I almost always come here for birthday cakes, and have tried almost all of them. The like the mousse cakes the best! Tie between Mango mousse and Strawberry mousse. The chestnut cake is also high up there on the rankings. I don't particularly like the green tea cake though, a bit bitter. Oh man, and the cake rolls with the cream swirls are really cheap and delicious! 

The buns here are pretty good but they are a bit expensive, at LEAST $1 per bun. BUT if you come here at 7:00pm there's a special: 2 buns for $1.50. They close at 7:30 so you should come here 5-10 minutes before to beat the rush, yes.. there is usually a line of people with a tray full of buns (sometimes 2). My personal favorite is the pineapple custard and raisin bun, second would be either cream cheese bun or the white cream filled bun. 

Great place just might be a bit pricey.
author: Jay L.

description: Has all of the wonderful staples of an Asian bakery... all kinds of filled buns and ornate little cakes. I really love the Purple Queen dessert which consists of panna cotta, red beans, and taro pudding. It was a symphony of delicious flavors.
author: Aurora S.

description:
Positives:
Their breads seem fresh and the prices are generally cheap.

Negatives:
Their cakes are not that great and quite pricey! Also, in this modern era of ATMs and credit, they don't accept anything but cash!

Sorry folks but lately I've been on an anti "cash-only  restaurants" mission. There are so many competitors out there and with modern technology, who doesn't have a credit card machine? Besides, those stores are quite silly. They don't realize that people actually SPEND MORE and EAT MORE when cards are accepted. They think they're the only smart ones in outwitting the IRS...
author: Mashimaro M.

description: For $7 I ordered the taro root bun (2), red bean bun, puff pastry, and taro pastry with mochi inside. The taro root bun was really good but the filling was a bit lacking. The red bean bun was OK, the beans inside were a little too dry. The puff pastry took me by surprise because I didn't know it had a filling of some dried pork. That one I didn't really like so much. My favorite was the taro pastry with mochi inside. I wish I took a picture of it because it was so cute, it looked like a little purple rose. I didn't think it would have that much taro flavor but it did and the mochi in the center was a perfect compliment to the pastry on the outside. Although the price was kinda steep, $1.85 for the bite sized taro pastry, I'd still buy it again because I've never seen that before. I'm now kicking myself for not buying some more. Anyone taking a trip up there soon?? I'll pay you to buy me some!! =)
author: Lei S.

description:
I get over-whelmed and want one of everything whenever I come here and somehow only walk away with a loaf of their cheese-bread.  It's hard to explain...it's like a little kid trapped in a candy store and can't figure out what to get at the end.  I'm glad I live kinda far, else, I might just walk in everyday just to look around.

Their Mango Mousse cake are THE Best and the other cakes are good as well.  All the fruit cakes here are delicious and I have never disappointed with them.

With my loaf of cheese bread, I usually get my $1.50 milk tea - which is actually pretty okay.
author: Bessie T.

description:
Love their tarts and assorted baked goods.  a bit more expensive than most chinese bakeries, but I love how it comes in packages so it's all sanitary.  Except that it's not warm like the other bakeries and I guess you get one or the other... whichever you feel is the lesser of 2 evils or if it's sanitary v. great taste... whatever.

They prob. have the most selection at this location b/c it's the first store in SF Bay Area.  What I like best is their deal after 7pm where it's 2 baked good items for the price of 1.  

sometimes i come here to grab the cold sandwiches for work the next day.  I mean $2 for a sandwich?? can't get that anywhere.  And their bread stays soft for a couple days.. can't ask for more than that..
author: AhLin C.

description:
Buns buns buns oh how I love me some buns. Even though I don't eat pork (which eliminates half of the buns) I still love me some yummy yummy buns. Like red bean. Or taro. Or custard. YUM! YAY!

We took some along to Napa on a wine tasting adventure and they definitely came in handy for soaking up the vino.
author: Irene F.

description: Been coming here for the past couple of years for cheap and delicious Chinese pastries.  My favorite are the mini-moon cakes (red bean and green tea are my favs) Sheng Kee serve year round and the custard buns and tarts.  Definitely plan on coming here for dessert after eating at one of the many great Chinese/Vietnamese restaurants nearby
author: Ben T.

description: Love this place. I've been here every time I  visit SF. Love their Saseme Thin Cookie, Custard Bun, and Paper Cup Cake.
author: Joe C.

description: You really get what you pay for here. I definitely notice an increase in quality when I come here versus a chinatown bakery. I usually get the coconut bun, which is so delicious in the morning when it is fresh out of the oven. I also get the ham & cheese bun, which is good too but a little too overwhelming. At first, i thought the ham & cheese was better than the coconut bun but not anymore. This place also has some really nice looking cakes but they're quite pricey. The only reason I didn't give this place a full 5 stars is because they're really expensive for a bakery. I believe the cocunut bun is $1.19 which is outrageous for a bun. I can get a bigger one for 70cents in chinatown but of course the quality is not as good as this place's. Overall, come here if you want to splurge a little on a good quality bread. OMG, how can i forget about their taiwan toast. It's absolutely delicious. I know it's just plain bread but it tastes very good since Sheng Kee uses quality ingredients. Again, it is very pricey. A little of $5 for a full loaf.
author: Vivian L.

description:
In need of a cake?

Sheng Kee is a great place if you are in dire need of a cake for that special occasion. There are many selections of cake that will suit your needs such as a fruitcake, chocolate cake, coffee cakes etc. Prices are great too. All their cakes are not overwhelming sweet and are always very moist. Prices are very good as well.
author: David W.

description:
Mucho kudos on the variety of breads they bake...I love their coconut breads and their sweet potato is also a favorite. They offer wheat, white, pineapple custard bread as well. But stick to what you're willing to experiment with.

I found that if you french toast the coconut bread, it gives off an amazing flavor. 

Cash only, but I haven't found a chinese bakery that accepts credit cards.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Yummy breads and cakes here. They used to put a lot more cream cheese in their breads but the past few years, they've been kinda stingy.

The cakes are all beautiful and the price reflects it. The last cake I tried was the green tea and red beans cake. It was how shall I put it? It was "interesting". It wasn't bad yet it was good. 

I haven't been there for the "7pm" sale but I hope to one day witness this for myself.

Too bad they don't take credit cards.

EDIT 2/21/08

I originally gave them 5 stars, but I had to drop it down to 3. I bought some buns and they had so little filling. It was mainly just the bun. That is not cool. I don't want to eat just a bun! I will not be purchasing any of their buns but will continue to buy the cakes.

I've only been to Sheng Kee at the Daly City location because my sister lives nearby there, but never knew I had one in my backyard as well!

Absolutely love the custard buns... actually, I'm eating one as I'm writing this review! Also love the little hot dog buns.  Can't wait to get more...

Screw it, I'm going there later today to get more.
author: Serge S.

description: Had the egg bread and now it is a weekly staple in our house.  Put peanut butter on it and you will see what I love so much.  Delicious!
author: Desmo K.

description: My family and I have been going to Sheng Kee for years!!!! I am a huge fan of their sponge cakes, because they use fruit moose and fruit to top the cake or put it inside the cake. I also LOVE their Pork Buns and their moon cakes. I would say though their ordered cake always testes much better then their ready made cakes, but they are still good!!! This is a must bakery to check out in the Outer Sunset!!
author: T C.

description: Bake goods are good, but the price has been going up & up.  Do not expect any good customer service they basically has a tiny counter space not enough space for people to pay for their goods, & they never say hello or thank you to the customer.  Is a dessert place so lighten it up!
author: Kat K.

description:
I used to come here a lot when my oldest bro lived in the area.  He would always have old, expired food in his fridge and on the tables and would only order take out so I would have to grab my own food before heading over there or risk starving.

Sheng Kee served me well when I didn't want to go into a restaurant and order take out and just wanted a few buns.

I liked their tuna bun, good 'ol cocktail bun, cream puff bun and so on.  Luckily whenever I went, it wasn't ever too busy.

Their cakes were good when I first started eating them but I got tired of the texture and wanted something more close to American spongy cakes but not so loaded with sugar.

Some of their prices can be a tad on the steep side for me tho.
author: Gilbert C.

description: They have very delicious coconut, taro, pineapple and red bean pastries. Yum yum. Their breads are also very fresh and delicious and good just to eat by themselves. They also have a wide range of chinese cakes which are all very delicious. I like their mini cheesecakes which are around $9.  I didn't realize this, but they also have these special taro pastries which my bf brought back for me from Taiwan. Sheng Kee has their own version and they sell six of them for $10.99 in a pretty box. You can also buy them individually.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Warm custard bun on a foggy day = post-pho bliss.  I have only had the custard bun here but it was fluffy and creamy in ways that other custard buns in my life have not been.  Don't tell anyone, but I am secretly on a quest for the perfect custard bun (despite being dead set against sweets -- I hate sweets!!!)  This one came pretty close.  Because it was not overly sweet!  But I will have to go back and sample more to be sure. ;-)

Update: their Japanese cheesecake with fruit topping is also very nice.
author: Molasses C.

description: I love their cakes with the chestnut filling! The fruits in the cake is very freshh! and the cake is moist too! Also the custard bread loaf! I love custard! The ham with corn bun tastes like how it would taste. Hmm but it sucks that most chinese bakery uses lard, margarine, and etc.
author: Janet Z.

description: I love Sheng Kee for their buns. Esp pineapple buns. And spongecake. And everything else pineapple. But hands down the best part of this place is the variety of cakes they have, for a decent, affordable price! Nobody DOESN'T get a Sheng Kee cake for special occasions.
author: Cindy S.

description: So affordable, and we got a great shot of the Golden Gate driving down 19th Street.  My kids really enjoyed the shredded pork bun and milk tea.  So nice being back home in the bay!!
author: Marisa I.

description:
Great strawberry whipped cream and sponge cake. It is not that horrible buttercream and 2 cups of sugar to make you sick kind of Bakery. Just really fresh, made that day good.

Pre-order your cakes here. Good prices for delicious sheet cakes.

Parking sharks here, watch those FOBs that think its like the 30 Stockton run on and crash into my car and I will sue you for the value of your $800,000 house Mrs. Wong.
author: miriam b.

description:
This place is really good if you like bake goods... the price range is ok..but  the food is really good. If you walk in and looked straight ahead...displaying to the public are the most wonderful and delicious cakes that you will ever taste (or seen) in your life.They are so0o good!! I recommend getting one to eat either for an occasion or just for yourself.

I love their sponge cakes...but most of the time I get their pineapple bun.
author: Maile W.

description:
Growing up, I always have this squared-like type of bread from my neighborhood bakery. I can never forget that taste. The perfect dough-processed with soft white bread feeling. As I get to the U.S, I just found that taste again from Sheng Kee Bakery. 

Get their White loaf of bread, Bun with Dried-minced pork jerkey on top and their Cocktail bun. 

If it can brings back the good memory of my childhood, then it can totally brings you so much JOY too...

Treat yourself & buy the nicest warm breads in the morning, when you only need to pay so little money.
author: Inne S.

description:
I use to come here a lot for the loaves of bread. But since the prices for wheat and flour have gone up, so has the prices here. My mom came in for the raisin loaf and it was about $4. I haven't bought a loaf of bread since prices have risen so high. I'm forced to get normal bread from Safeway. Boo! The prices of the freshly baked individual wrapped buns have risen slightly. I still get the shredded pork bun, freshly baked Portuguese egg custard tart and the individual cake slices (mocha). They offer individually wrapped buns for half off for an hour before closing. I don't know if they still offer this discount. 

I like the cakes here. In particular are the strawberry-mango mousse cake and the mocha mousse cake. These cakes have been received positively received at family functions. There is a good balance between the lightly whipped mousse and the moist cake on the bottom. These cakes come with a price - the small one is $22.95.  But oh so worth it!
author: Candace F.

description: Nice to have a dessert/cake house in the neighborhood. I would give 5 stars if they served more Chinese desserts like egg tarts.
author: Anthony W.

description: I was kind of overwhelmed here because there didn't seem to be any order to the chaos.  I just walked in and followed what other people were doing and the people who worked there were just chatting among themselves instead to helping customers.  Whatever.  I got a taro bun for $1.80 and it was super good.  It was the middle of the day and it still tasted fresh.  I saw people paying with a card.  The register sign said you can pay with a card if it's over $15, but the people in front of me used it to pay for something that was like $9, so maybe they aren't that strict about it?  I would definitely go back here and try something else.  The tables were clean, too.
author: k h.

description: Their cakes are yumm. Cake is firm and fluffy and the cream is bouncy. We got a fruit topped cake for my mummy's bday here. Kiwi, Strawberry and peach galore. The only thing i didnt like are the stripes of strawberry jam embedded into the cake--made it too sweet. You can expect consistent deliciousness here.
author: Amy S.

description: Love, love, Love their variety of buns:  pork sung, taro, red bean, & chocolate mochi filled pineapple bun (looks like pineapple, not tastes like pineapple).  But what happened to the chocolate mochi bolo bow?  Irving St. & Westlake doesn't make it anymore.  I crave for those.  Does any of the Sheng Kees still make them?
author: Jeannie C.

description: Solid-love getting a pastry or treat on my way to the beach.
author: Melanie M.

description:
3.5 stars

After waking up and taking my dog for a stroll in GGP on a saturday morning, my stomach starts to grumble a bit and my mind starts thinking about what I want to munch on.  Quick take-out? sandwich fom andronicos? congee? So as I'm driving up Irving, I see a parking space near sheng kee and decide .. Ah! ill just grab some buns to snack on.  I come to sheng kee pretty often, but alot of them time I leave a little unsatisfied.  You can't go wrong with the loaves of bread, but the individual assorted buns are a little of a let down sometimes.  For a snack I usually grab some of those pre-made half sandwiches or chicken pot pies.  When my sweet tooth is kicking extra hard, i like to pick up some taiwanese candies.  They have a lot of fancy cakes to look at, but in my opinion they dont taste as good as they look.
author: david w.

description: The cake taste is not bad, but that is the only part that I went back !   The lone line, the bad service and the attitude is just terribly  horrible !!!  Totally unprofessional !!!  I got in line like everybody else, wait it about 15 + minutes to order a b-day cake for a special occasion.  Pay and need to wait another 30 minutes for the birthday letters.  Fine.... patiently wait it.... came back over 30 minutes.  Saw someone on the side table doing nothing with the Sheng Kee uniform on.  Ask her that I have pay for the cake, waiting for the words.    Can you please just bring it out for me, Please.  Ask her very nicely.  Some nerve, she said I am on a coffee break !  Go get in Line !!!!   With an attitude !!!   Some nerve.   I mean all she has to do is just take 10 seconds to get it  for me.  About the cake that I have pay and is all rape up, all ready to go.   But instead she when straight back to the cash register.   If I wasn't in a hurry for a party.  I would just left and go somewhere else to buy another cake....... is not like they're the only bakery in the bay area.  piss me off,  never again.    Schubert's on Clement Street has better cakes and much better services.
author: Steffon Y.

description: Why aren't there more Chinese bakeries on Irving? It's our bread and butter kind of breakfast and snacks!
author: T L.

description: Bond likes his Martini's shaken not stirred. Charlie Brown likes the Little Red Headed Girl. Brittany Spears likes exposing her junk. An' I love Japanese baked goods...right down to the tasteful packaging.  But recently I was surprised to taste the light airy flavor of a Sheng Kee cake. Wonderful flavor without being overpowering or dry. Though a chocolate morsel from Tokyo will always retain my focus, the SKB fruit cake is an acceptable, temporary distraction.  Butcha gotta git to the Sunset to get....
author: Johnny C.

description: Despite the fact that I don't understand any of what's printed on them, I really enjoy the tiny red bean mooncakes here... and anything made of taro.  Something that's naturally purple in color just has to be good.  The atmosphere is diner-like and the staff is helpful.
author: Bert M.

description: I love dropping by early in the mornings and picking up a fresh, just out of the oven loaf of custard bread. Makes for a convenient breakfast and snack. I'm always tempted by the other pastries and cookies but have stayed loyal to my custard loaf and every once in a while, a coconut cream bun. Try reheating it in the oven for a minute for sweet, coconutty bliss!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
The bao and cake here are delicious. Walking 20 avenues just to get some delicious. They're presented beautifully, with your eyes almost able to gorge on the look alone. The prices are lean too, with individual buns costing between $1-1.50 and slices at $2.50-3.50. I am a now a regular and make it a point to come here at least weekly.

Try the taro, red bean, custard or chocolate buns. The mango mouse was good too, but sadly not as "mangoey" as I was hoping. Very light and non-greasy foods here - a great sweet treat.
author: Delicious R.

description:
absolutely one of my favorite bakers since i was a kid. there are just some days when i'm totally craving the asian cakes. i think it's something about the spongy, light, cakes and the whole bits of fruit stuck in between each layer.

you MUST try the japanese cheesecake!
author: Mayson J.

description: Their sandwiches are best.  After 6PM they are half off.  Great deal!  The employees have a bit of an attitude though.
author: Jean Lee W.

description:
this is my one stop place for shredded pork bread (it sounds better in chinese) and tiramisu!

i found a new love...

their little triangle spongey cake things... (it has two flavors chocolate and strawberry) YUM! ill have to go and get some more 2m!
author: JUDY L.

description: I love their Pineapple buns and Green Onion bun! Their Mooncake is also one of the best around. My parents gave a box of Sheng Kee mooncake to my in-laws and my mother-in-law ate it all in 2 days! The secret to their delicious mooncake? Well, according to my brother who use to bang mooncakes from little molds at ShengKee, lard...lots and lots of lard! The prices are also a bit expensive for a bun. But, I recently found the secret to buying cheap Sheng Kee buns, go there at 8pm and everything gets marked down to half the regular price. At least thats what they do at the Sheng Kee at Skyline plaza. People start hovering around the pastry windows with trays around 7:50pm. As soon as 8:00pm come around and they put out the sign for the discount buns, people start grabbing buns like they're giving out free crack. I once had to fight some old lady for the last pineapple bun... Ahh, good fun..
author: Annie L.

description:
i love the pineapple taro buns!! its my favorite!

they have good cakes. i've tried their cheesecake before and didnt like it. black forest cake...eh its also okay. but their mango mousse cake is VERY YUMMY! they also have good bread.
author: B B.

description: Misleading label... why named a loaf of bread & bun "pineapple" if there is actually no pineapple....the shape of bread don't even look like pineapple either...I hope someday I can see some bread that has real pineapple inside...
author: Shun-ling L.

description:
i like coming here because i like their asian pastries! their cakes look so good and they taste good too! i've been coming here since 5th grade and i still come here once inna while. altho it's a bit pricey for their pastries like their moon cakes, but their really good. my girl and i use to stop by around 630(i can't quite remember.) their sandwiches goes on sale, so it's cheap. lol i usually save the sandwiches for dinner because i'm too lazy to make food. 

price are good for the quantity! 

just a heads up, they're cash only no credit card.
author: Valerie N.

description:
so it's 7:30am on a tuesday morning and the majority of the fresh buns aren't out of the oven yet. isn't this the prime time for people to come and get their breakfast? 

i couldn't get my bbq pork buns because they weren't ready yet. so i settled for the pineapple buns. too bad the pineapple crust was only spotted on the top of the bun. the bun itself was fresh and soft and fluffy. just the way i like. 

oh yeah, and who can start the morning without a cup of hot milk tea? i certainly can't. i looooove hk style milk tea.
author: Mei N.

description:
back in the day when i lived in the awful outer sunset (41st and judah), my friend lydia c, would always want to go to sheng kee whenever she visited.
the buns are pretty good... there are sweet ones as well as savory ones.  i don't think i've tried their cakes though
author: charlotte s.

description: Amazing pastries.  Really! The one thing that kills me is how much damn plastic that they use.  Everything is covered in platic in this place.  What a waste.
author: Mike M.

description:
the cakes here are really pretty but as others have said are overpriced.

i've purchased the fruit basket cake for $23 and they really do layer on the fruit! (i remember a lot of kiwi on it) however, besides the fruit, the rest of the cake is ok tasting...

i've also tasted the mango mousse cake from another location and that one is pretty delicious...same price i believe
author: Wendy T.

description: Sheng Kee is the best Chinese bakery in the Sunset. Their coconut rolls are my favorite... At 99 cents, how can you go wrong? Pop it in the microwave for 24 seconds, and when it comes out, unravel the sweet bread from its spiral shape, with yellow coconut flakes falling off, sprinkling the plate. At the end, scoop all the extra coconut into your mouth.. Heaven. They also make good melon cookies, dan tats (custard tarts), Portugese custard, red bean rolls, cocktail buns, and coconut BREAD (yummyyoo)! Everything is good except the big custard bun. I didn't like the custard in it. The cakes here are a little overpriced though - try Schubert's.
author: O K.

description: The selection here is MUCH better then those at the Richmond, CA location and the items seem fresher.  I bought some mini croissants (3 for $1.25) and they had a nice crunch but crumbled a lot while I ate them.  The service was a bit slow as well...two cashiers, 3 customers and it took several minutes to pay for my purchase.
author: J T.

description: Everytime I walk down Irving, I am drawn to the wonderful smells emanating from this store.  Their sweet breads and pineapple breads are very good.  Prices are reasonable too.
author: Grace M.

description:
it was quite cruel that hyphen magazine's booth ended up right outside the doors of this institution, for soon enough, we were heading in and out of this place, at a little more than a snail's pace.  

*drool*  man, those pineapple buns were good...
author: Jill k.

description: Sheng Kee makes delicious baked goods. Wowow. Like, all kinds of Chinese pastries. Their cakes are really good too. Not too sweet like those Safeway cakes. This place in particular is usually a bit crowded and there are at most like 2 cashiers so it takes a bit of time to pay for stuff, but their stuff is soo good.
author: M J.

description: Excellent sweet breads; every one I've tried has been delicious. And I like going in and looking at the freaky hot-dog-green-onion or tuna buns. Someday I'll probably even buy one.
author: Heather R.

description: 99 cent apple turnovers that will make your taste buds SING!!!
author: Keika L.

description: Its a pretty good bakery....The chocolate roll is off the hook!! OMG so good.  The cakes are decorated nicely and taste good.  However there is a price for the little decor....its pricey.  I grew up in Chinatown, so i know the usual cost for the buns and this place is charging waaaay too much for the usual buns; cocktail, pineapple, BBQ pork etc.  In chinatown you can usually get more for the same price and it actually taste good too..  But this is the place to go for cakes and the rolls....MmMMm.
author: Shirley H.

description: The buns seem freshly made but I don't know what kind of flour they used. The texture of the buns just dont go right. I guess people buy buns there probably because they don't have many choices here.
author: Erica C.

description: This place individually wraps their baked goods to make it seem more upscale and classy, but that does not make their stuff better tasting. I've had so much better at locations that are not too flattering, but its not about appearance, its about the food. Don't waste extra money here when you can save and get so much more at an authentic Chinese Bakery.
author: Maggie C.

description: This bakery is sooooo reminiscent of the bakeries I would go to with my Grandma whenever I would go visit her in Japan. The highlights of my forced childhood family trips... bakeries and the infamous electronic gadget district in Tokyo.... anyways, yes this place has fresh patries. the aroma of butter just draws you in and I can never leave here buying just one roll.... cheese, corn, and ham bun? mooncakes? hotdog and cheese roll??? puff pastries filled with curried beef???? oh how to choose how to choose?????
author: Marina K.

description: Raisin bread...get some!!!  Oh, pass on the egg custard tarts, though...you can find tastier, flakier ones elsewhere.
author: Joyce L.

description: I come here for their custard bread.  It is one of my staple foods.  The red bean or dry shredded pork bread is good too.
author: Mick S.

description: What can I say? This is the place where those dreaded Chinese cakes come from. I mean, it's not a bad cake, but shit.. they all taste the same! I swear!! Other than that, they have nice little pastries and rolls to try. I can't say I've tried them all, but by far I'm always munching on a few here and there for breakfast in class. Every ones always asking me if I made that shit or something. HAHA funny peoples.
author: Andrew W.

description: Stupid amounts of bread, stupid prices ($0.99 for a hot dog & cheese bun!?), stupid crazy good chinese slogans equate to a stupid good cheap eat. I just wish it had ambiance, or else I would eat in there with my fly gear, stuntin'.
author: Haz O.

description: I love their coconut bread. My parents have been coming here for bread for years now.
author: Jen P.

description: If you like bread, and haven't tried Sheng Kee's "Taiwanese bread" yet, you must! I have absolutely no idea where the origin of this bread is, but it's very common in Japan and something I missed a lot in the US. It's a white bread, almost perfectly square, and soft but with sufficient density to stand up to toppings or as a sandwich. Definitely one of the best breads for toast, french toast, or a sandwich! Sheng Kee also has tons of filled buns, and the taro one comes highly recommended.
author: Will A.

description:
My review: There are a lot of Sheng Kee Bakeries out there. I have bought many pastries and cakes there before. The workers are really nice and it's pretty darn cheap compared to other bakeries. I recommend a person to try it here at least once.
Rumor I've heard: They scrape off the mold on cakes and put it back outside.
author: M M.

description: This is the place to go for the goodies. They have this really tasty egg tart. There's two types, only the one that is a bit over $1 is tasty. Its even better than the ones from the Golden Mountain or something like that on Grant in Chinatown. Plus service is much better. I LOVE their chocolate mousse cake. There's like 3 different layers of delicious chocolatey-ness. The corn and harm bun isn't bad either. I never had bad experience with any of the workers here. Plus I remember I got something free here too. This is probably my favorite Chinese Bakery, thus far.
author: Audrey M.

description:
not known for low prices but always good quality, and every location is freakin' clean, unlike most local chinese bakeries

they put everything in a really cool box, too

the coconut rolls are also good. hella good. like "holy crap i just ate seven of them???" kind of good.
author: Charles C.

description:
i ordered cakes alot from this bakery in the past year. throughout the year of 2006, i been moving around and tried other cake places around bay area. for this Christmas, i ordered mango raspberry cakes from here, because of time limitation. i brought this cake with confident remembering the past experiences that i had. 
after Christmas dinner, i cut the cake... everybody was like uuh oohh, how beautiful cake is...
but, after i taste it... it was sucks !! everybody else didn't say anything, i don't think they dare to say something.. but seriously either they change the chef or the try to change some quality ingredient to cheaper stuff.. i don't know...

even the regular Taiwan toast are sucks ! not moist and fresh enough.
i will stick with Schubert next time i have to buy a desert ! 

thanks for your embarrassing moment, sheng kee
author: sherly A.

description: I love almost everything here.  The breads, rolls  and cakes.  I don't even know where to start.  Just try everything from this bakery.  The coconut toast, cream cheese toast and pork sung are my favorites.  I love the mocha roll here.  Recently, I ordered a mocha chocolate cake here for my sister's bday it was really yummy.  The japanese cheesecake is very fluffy...I didn't get a chance to have a slice the last time we ordered one.  You can't go wrond if you order a cake here.
author: Allison T.

description: Great selection at a great price. Tried their shredded pork bun and egg tarts and red bean mooncake pastry and it was all good. Will definitely come back and try more next time...I am thinking of definitely trying some of their baked pastries too such as the curry beef horn...oooooo.....
author: Topazskye L.

description: This is the closest place to satisfy my pineapple bun craving. The ones they make aren't quite as good as some of the ones I've had from Chinatown bakeries, but they're still pretty darn good. Based on other reviews, I'll have to try some of the other sweet breads.
author: Kathleen B.

description: I love the clean and modern atmosphere of this place. Their simple baked goods are something I always look forward to when I'm in the area. I'm obsessed with red bean and they have it in several great varieties including the basic red bean bun or pineapple bun. Cheap and great food, and a nice place to hang around in a nutshell!
author: Steven S.

description: This  place is pretty good if u are a munchie person. I used to come here as a kid getting the flakey stuffed chicken bun, jelly rolls and sponge cakes. Now, I come when I get a major craving for my childhood cravings.
author: Jason C. J.

description: Mmm.. custard raisin loaf bread, slices of yummyness.
author: Sara D.

description:
I would replace an entire meal just for two PorkSung baos. 
I (think) they're $1.35 each now.. And I dig through the whole tray to find the biggest one with the most PorkSung on top. 
I do think that there is a bit too much butter, but I'm quite biased... I hate butter.

Anyways, the cakes are cute even though I'm not much of a mousse-cake type of girl.  Almost identical to the ones from Schubert's... although I must say I prefer the latter.
author: Diana W.

description: I LOVE this place! Their breads are made daily, and their nightly special thing where it's like 50% off is a way to prove it. So if you go get something in the middle of the day, you know it hasn't been sitting there for weeks. It's really clean too! And their cakes taste& look awesome!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Their cakes are really fluffy, not heavy, consistently tasty.  Great birthday cake options and we will not go anywhere else!
Pastries are good here as well.
You do have to have CASH to pay, parking can be challenging.
author: Miinno N.

description: I LOVE Shenh Kee and take every opportunity that I can to stop in for custard buns and hot dog buns.  I also like anything they make with pineapple in it (I don't think the "pineapple buns" actually have pineapple in them, but other pastries do).  The service is unique.  No pleasantries, no b.s.  They ring you up promptly and get you out the door.  These people don't mess around--they are the definition of efficient.  On occasion I get a friendly smile though.  My only complaint is that I think their cocktail buns need some work.
author: Kandi K.

description: My co-workers at Saks 5th gave me a cake for my birthday, it is quite far where I live now, but I'll try to go back and get their cheese bread, even my 80 year old father liked it.  They should put one store here in Union Square.
author: sfbutterfly l.

description:
Their bread is not so good, it is just an ordinary bread, not tasty and a bit dry. I like Utane Toast from Ranch 99 Foster City better because it is softer and very tasty especially when you toast it.  The price is also cheaper.

I only buy the cakes (tiramisu or fruit cake) for friend's birthday from them and they are good! Also the sandwich is pretty good for a little snack between lunch and dinner.
author: sofie W.

description: I picked up a strawberry birthday cake and it was lovely!  The cake had glazed fruit on top, light and not-too-sweet frosting that did not sog the pound cake, and cute decorative flourishes (swirly design on the side, fruit artfully arranged).  I ate a coconut bun while waiting and it was yummy too.  I reccommend!  The person who asked me to pick up the cake assured me that it would be cheap, but the cake cost $20.  Is that what these things go for these days?
author: Eleanor E.

description:
DON'T go to this place

- the people working there are RUDE. they just want you to pay and leave and are unfriendly.

- DON'T do custom orders here. I've verified with them twice of my custom order and it didn't turn out as ordered. their displays of cake looks nice, but BEWARE, your order does not look like that!
author: sleepy b.

description:
cakes are artistic and tasty, especially the mousses 
buns are buttery and sugary - usually fresh 
bread is just buttery - always fresh during the right times of day
swiss rolls are cold - good deal if you're in the mood for ONE slice 
mooncakes are the best - they have the best non-yolk fillings around, especially the black date paste [dou saa] inside 

side note - sheng kee tends to be a little overpriced than other bakeries within the irving corridor radius.
author: Court L.

description:
-this happened bout a year ago
-is it their goal to piss off customers? or only the ones not of their race?
-i came here to pick up a cake dressed as a pirate for a themed birthday party
-after the stares, found out they only take cash so i run out to the car to where my man handed me cash
-parking is a biatch by the way
-upon ringing me up, i found out i was 25 cents short and, that was all the cash we had
-i was asking the customers if they can spare a quarter, looking like a pirate and they all "pretended" not to understand fucken english.....
-great! i leave the cake on the counter and run back to the car to fucken look for a fucken quarter prolle on the floor of the car or up my ass
-my man found while digging in his wallet a 2 dollar bill he's kept in there for ages, with a heavy heart we use that to pay their fucken quarter
-it felt like a trya banks social experiment "will people treat you differently if you're a pirate"- no shieyt sherlock!
-i went to another one of their bakeries in san jose and actually commented on their service there too, i didn't know they were branched till today!
-1point cuz the cake did taste good
-i walk out of there looking like a pirate to a leathered acura cl with navi, my authentic prada purse with matching wallet, with a great job making bout 70 g's a year and to my CPA boyfriend feeling like crap
=YOU MIGHT HAVE EVERYTHING BUT..... FUCKING 25 CENTS (totally forgot about the $200 CASH! i had in a card in my bag as a bonus from my boss, fucken ey)
author: serbelle i.

description: love this place! sheng kee is one of the best asian bakeries around, i just wish they were closer to me...cakes are yummy, pretty and well worth the 5 stars. one of my favorite things aside from the cakes is the green tea  with red bean swiss roll thingy. love. love. love.
author: meL Z.

description: I like how everything is individually wrapped here. I know it's bad for the environment but I find it really cute for some reason. Anyway, if I'm in the area I grab a couple of buns before grabbing the 28/29 to school. So far everything's been good. Not a big fan of the BBQ pork, but all the dessert-y type stuff gets my seal of approval; I think the red bean is the best out of all the kinds I've tried and I'm usually not a red bean person!
author: melissa f.

description:
fear not the sheng kee, oh sf newbie.  yes, it can be intimidating to not be able to read the chinese characters.  and perhaps you know not of the flavors of a pork sung bun ( i don't), or even taro root.  but, young butterfly, allow yourself a chance to follow the way of the sheng kee and yee shall find a pathway toward enlightenment (or more likely not, i'm just grasping for an intro here). 

ok, hows this... i imagine a music video for "the scale" from the new interpol album.  in the video, i peruse through the many different buns.  trying to decide between a pinapple and a custard.  as my eyes scan left and right, they work in concert with my brain attempting to process the resulting tastes of the various pedestrian and exotic buns (i think i quoted the title of an adult video just now).  and then my hands reach to jostle the different bins, as if i've got epidermal taste buds that can pierce through the crisp plastic wrappers, giving me insight on which of the many buns would maximize my satisfaction (whoa, we're deep in the adult video section).  all the while, elder statesmen and queens of the sheng kee secret society jaunt in and gather their deserving booty with utter confidence (gee, i hope sister joan from the catholic grade school i attended doesn't read this.)  i make note.  and then as i begin to head toward the counter, a warm new batch of mystery buns is stocked on the shelves.  i spin around, rehash my decision and question my snack choosing ability.  what?  shall i be mocked for going for the hot dog and onion bun ?  i've lost my mind.  what am i thinking ?

4 stars for the coconut custard bun.  man oh meng.  thats where you should be.  put down that ham, corn, and cheese bun please.  get it together.  maybe after 4 beers at pac bell with the giants down by 5 and zito long gone.  the coconut custard bun.  buy one for the trip back to the car.  one for later as the evening snack.  and one more for the next morning with the coffee.  then go to your local 24 hour fitness, sit through the speech to get you to sign up (but resist to the best of your ability), and get your free workout.

ps.  do stay away from their coffee.
author: Ed S.

description: went here and picked up: taro bun, red bean bun, custard bun, pineapple bread and a large (cake size) fruit tart.  the fruit tart was pretty good and didn't have an awful syrup flavor to it.  the buns held up well and stayed soft for breakfast through the week although the custard bun was too buttery and sweet for my taste.  maybe i lucked out, but all of them had an ample amount of filling inside.  the pineapple bread was really yummy at first but started to get stale after the first couple of days.  i'd definitely go back and try more stuff, but now i know to be more careful with storage for the rest of the week.
author: Aparna B.

description: sheng kee bakery cakes are a staple at every family event we have because they are just sooo good. i know the chinese bakery goods are what they are known for but try the taro cake, the black forest cake (chocolate with cherries), the mango mousse cake, and the tiramisu. and the mooncakes here are amazing too. try the pineapple ones if you're just getting started with them.
author: Jessica W.

description: Overall, their cakes and buns are very good. I love them all, just a little pricy. Their stores are usually very new and clean. For all my kids and friends birthdays, I got it from them. It is expensive, but its all worth it. However, there was one incident, I wasn't happy about their service. I came pick up my daughter's bday cake. Then they told me they made a mistake, my cake wasn't there. They told me to get a different one. How can I just get another one? Its a kids bday, I had made plans to make a special party for her, the design of the cake was specially picked. You can imagine how frustrated I was. They said they could make one but I had to return in the afternoon. If they offered me a half price or a cake for free, I wouldnt be so mad. No, they didnt! Thats not a good way to do business. Especially to a customer like me, i've been buying so many cakes from them. They made the mistake, they should have given me a free cake or at least a discount. I was very angry that day, ruined my daughter's bday too!
author: The Black Cat C.

description: the BEST chinese bakery in USA, Sheng Kee is a International Brand Name, Unlike other mom and pop chinese bakery normally outside clean but kitchen super dirty, Sheng Kee always can trust and believe.
author: Michelle W.

description: maybe because i had too much of this place. this place is regularly my breafast on daily basis and i'm kinda sick of it. i wish they do come out with some better delicious bread stuff rather then the same stuff all the time. they should have more variety or just switch off more often. they are still good compared to a lot of other bakeries out there.
author: Eric Y.

description: the buns here are awesome. always fresh and yummy. their cakes look delicious but too bad theyre kinda pricy. another con is that they dont accept cards. i always use card!! overall,  their buns are great!
author: Rhonda H.

description: This place is horrible.  Their services suck.  On April 27, 2009, I bought  a birthday cake for my friend and asked the cashier to write the name on it but she only gave the sign to put on the cake. That night, when my friend opened the box, the cake was already cut and was spoiled.  My friend was really disappointed, and it was her birthday too !   Whatever you do, don't buy cakes here !!
author: Fanny L.

description: mm i love there loafs of red bean bread.. its making me fat.. but its so good! i cant trust myself when i have it laying on my table.. i also bought the coconut mooncake which was nasty.. tasted really greasy. and the green tea mooncake. that was ok. but come here for the bread=) its super cheap too!
author: christy w.

description: everything there is fresh. beautiful cakes, mouth watering! if they screw up the shape of a baked good or something is not as fresh, it goes to the cheaper pile to be sold for less. cake is a must, so creamy and deliecious!
author: Kelly L.

description: The food is pretty good, but I'm not that much in favor of chain stores.
author: Cindy W.
